editionStmt.edition: This early release includes some 500 EEBO-TCP transcriptions of Early Modern plays that have undergone several routines to create an interoperable and algorithmically amenable corpus of Early Modern Drama. Many incompletely or incorrectly transcribed words have been corrected, including obvious printers' errors, but the text has not been proofread word by word. Each word in the text has been identified as a distinct token with its own xml:id and assigned to a lemma, a part of speech, and a standard spelling. Speech prefixes were mapped to unique speaker ID's as "who" attributes of sp elements. elements

respStmt.resp: Incompletely or incorrectly transcribed words were reviewed and in many cases fixed by
respStmt.name: Nicole Sheriko

respStmt.resp: Tokenization and linguistic annotation using MorphAdorner and NUPOS 2.0 were provided by
respStmt.name: Philip R. Burns

respStmt.resp: With the help of Thomas L. Berger's Index of Characters in Early Modern English Drama Printed Plays, 1500-1660 speech prefixes were mapped to unique "who" attributes of sp elements by
respStmt.name: Martin Mueller

respStmt.resp: A provisional, rudimentry, and algorithmically produced castlist was added as a new div in the back listing each role with their number of speeches sorted from high to low by
respStmt.name: Martin Mueller

respStmt.resp: Project co-ordination and review of textual changes and linguistic annotation by
respStmt.name: Martin Mueller

list.head: The actors names.
list.item: Master Dissuader, sir William Holdfast's friend.
The lady prudence, daughter and heir to the lord sage.
The lady mute, the affianced mistress to sir Thomas Letgo.
The lady jealousy, sir Henry Courtly's lady.
Three of four old ladies, the mothers to the four young ladies.

list.head: The wooers.
list.item: As, the soldiers, the country gentleman, the courtier, the bashful and his friend, the amorous, the divine, the lawyer, the citizen, the farmer, the stranger, all wooers.

div.head: Prologue.
div.l: Our authoress says to make a play is hard,
To censure freely men are not afraid;
Opinions easily do pass upon
The wit of others, though themselves have none;
And envy rounds the sense, and words about,
Hoping some errors it may soon find out.
But streams of wit do not so often flow,
As salt rough censures, which to billows grow;
And swell so big, till they in pieces fall,
In their own ruins they are buried all.
But if our author's play deserves a praise,
She will not thank you, though you give her bays;
Because she knows it is her right and due,
And justice to receive the same from you.
Wherefore she says, if you do take delight
To read her play, or acted to your sight,
The bounty doth proceed from her alone;
Her wit doth pleasure give to every one.
The play, if bad, she doth desire no praise,
The cypress will receive instead of bays.

sp.speaker: 1 man.
sp.p: 'Tis reported that the great mogul hath war with the Parthians, and a man of our nation is general of all his forces.

sp.speaker: 2 man.
sp.p: methinks it is too great an honour and trust to give to a stranger.

sp.speaker: 1 man.
sp.p: But it is reported he hath behaved himself so wisely, honestly, nobly, and valiantly, as he hath gained the favour of the emperor, and love of the soldiers, and also respect from all the inferior princes.

sp.speaker: 2 man.
sp.p: Who should this man be?

sp.speaker: 1 man.
sp.p: I cannot learn: for the merchants from whom I had this report, know not what his right name is; for they think he goeth by a covered name.

sp.speaker: 2 man.
sp.p: Surely he is of a very mean birth, that he is ashamed to own his name.

sp.speaker: 1 man.
sp.p: It seems so; but let his birth be poor or great, he hath a generous soul: for they say he is very bountiful, and lives in great magnificence, and carries himself as if he were princely born: he is the whole discourse upon the exchange, and the merchants do cry him up like to another Julius Caesar.

sp.speaker: 2 man.
sp.p: It seems they fare the better for his being their countryman, and he to be the emperor's favourite.

sp.speaker: 1 man.
sp.p: 'Tis like enough.

sp.speaker: 2 man.
sp.p: Nay you may be assured they have a fee of obligation, if they praise him so much. Of what age do they say he may be?

sp.speaker: 1 man.
sp.p: They say is in the prime of his years, a very handsome man, well-behaved, and of a ready wit.

sp.speaker: 2 man.
sp.p: 'Tis strange it should not be known of what parentage he is of.

sp.speaker: 1 man.
sp.p: It is not known as yet.

sp.speaker: 1 man.
sp.p: Sir, were not you a servant to the lord of Sage?

sp.speaker: 2 man.
sp.p: Yes sir.

sp.speaker: 1 man.
sp.p: He was a wise, and a noble person.

sp.speaker: 2 man.
sp.p: He was so, heaven rest his soul.

sp.speaker: 1 man.
sp.p: 'Tis said he hath left but one only child, and she a daughter, which daughter is sole heir to all his estate.

sp.speaker: 2 man.
sp.p: She is so.

sp.speaker: 1 man.
sp.p: And it is also reported she will be wooed in public, or else she'll never wed.

sp.speaker: 2 man.
sp.p: The report is true, sir: for I am now going to invite all her friends and acquaintance, to whom she desires to publish her resolutions.

sp.speaker: 1 man.
sp.p: Is she resolved of it?

sp.speaker: 2 man.
sp.p: She hath vowed it.

sp.speaker: 1 man.
sp.p: Pray favour me so much, as to give me a character of her.

sp.speaker: 2 man.
sp.p: She is virtuous, young, beautiful, graceful, and hath a supernatural wit; and she hath been bred and brought up to all virtuosus, which adorns her natural gifts; she lives magnificently, yet orders her estate prudently.

sp.speaker: 1 man.
sp.p: This lady may be a sample to all her sex.

sp.speaker: 1 matron.
sp.p: Mistress simple is the veriest fool that ever I tutored or instructed.

sp.speaker: 2 matron.
sp.p: Do you mean a fool by imprudence, or a fool that speaks improperly?

sp.speaker: 1 matron.
sp.p: I do not know what her imprudence may be; but in her words there is no coherence.

sp.speaker: 2 matron.
sp.p: Alas she is young; and youth is a cage of ignorance, and boys and girls are like birds, which learn from their tutors and tutoresses artificial tunes, which are several languages, sciences, arts, and the like: but the truth is, of all sorts of birds, the cocks are more apt to learn than the hens.

sp.speaker: 1 matron.
sp.p: If she can be taught sense, I am much mistaken: for she hath not a reasonable capacity to learn.

sp.speaker: 2 matron.
sp.p: Why then she hath a defect in nature, as a changeling.

sp.speaker: 1 matron.
sp.p: I think so.

sp.speaker: 2 matron.
sp.p:
Why should you think so, since youth's capacity cannot be measured by their educators? for time is the only measure of the rational capacity: and to prove it, some boys and girls will be so dull, as to seem stupid to learning, and yet in their strength of years may prove very rational understanding,
and wise men or women; besides, the brain is like to the air, 'tis sometimes thick with misty errors, sometimes dark with clouds of ignorance, and sometimes clear with understanding, whenas the sun of knowledge shines; and perchance you heard her speak when her brain was cloudy and dark.

sp.speaker: 1 matron.
sp.p: So dark, as her words could not find the right way to sense.

sp.speaker: 2 matron.
sp.p: Perchance if you hear her speak some other times, when her brain is clear, you may hear her speak wisely.

sp.speaker: 1 matron.
sp.p: It is so unlikely she should ever speak wisely, as it is near to impossible.

sp.speaker: 2 matron.
sp.p: Indeed unlikely and impossible do some way resemble each other: but let me tell you, the brain is like the face, it hath its good days and its bad: for beauty and wit have not only their times and seasons, but their foul and fair days.

sp.speaker: 1 matron.
sp.p: You say true: for the choicest beauties that ever were, or are, will sometimes look worse than at other times; nay so ill they will look sometimes, as they might be thought they were not beauties.

sp.speaker: 2 matron.
sp.p: The like for wit: for certainly, the greatest wit that ever was, or is, may sometimes be so dull and unactive, as it might be thought they were so far from being wits, as they might be judged fools: and certainly, the most eloquent orators that ever were, have spoke at some times less eloquently than at other times; insomuch, that at some times, although the subject of their discourse is so full of matter and reason, as might have oiled their tongues, smoothed their words, and enlightened their fancy, yet they will speak as if their wits had catched cold, and their tongues had the numb palsy, on which their words run stumbling out of their mouths as insensible; whenas at other times, although the subject of their discourse be barren or boggy, woody or rocky, yet their wit will run a race without stop or stay, and is decked and adorned with flowery rhetoric: and certainly, the wisest men that ever were, have given both themselves and others worse counsel sometimes, than at other times; and certainly the valiantest man that ever was, had sometimes more courage than at other times: but yet although a valiant man may have more courage at one time than another, yet he is at no time a coward, nor a wise man a fool.

sp.speaker: 1 matron.
sp.p: But orators may chance to speak nonsense.

sp.speaker: 2 matron.
sp.p: They may so, and many times do.

sp.speaker: 1 matron.
sp.p: Why then may not a valiant man be at some times a coward, and a wise man a fool, as well as orators to speak nonsense?

sp.speaker: 2 matron.
sp.p: Because valour, judgement, and prudence are created in the soul, and is part of its essence; I do not mean every soul, but the souls of valiant and wise men: for souls differ as much as bodies, some are created defective, others perfect; but words are only created in the mouth, and are born through the lips, before the soul of sense is entered or inbodied therein.

sp.speaker: 1 matron.
sp.p: An orator's tongue is powerful.

sp.speaker: 2 matron.
sp.p: An orator's tongue doth rather play on passions, than compose the judgement, or set notes to the reason; like as a fiddler, that can play tunes on musical instruments, but is no musician, to compose and set tunes: but there are many men that have eloquent tongues, but not witty souls; they have the art of words, but not the spirit of wit.

div.head: Scene 4.
div.stage: Enter the lady prudence, and a company of ladies and knights, whom she had invited to hear her resolutions. She stands by herself, and speaks.

sp.speaker: Lady prudence.
sp.p: Kind friends, and worthy acquaintance, you may think it strange, and perchance take it ill, I invite you only to a simple discourse, for to declare a vain vow, as you may judge it so to be, which vow I made since my father the lord Sage's death. The vow is, never to receive a lover's address, or to answer a lover's suit but in a public assembly; and 'tis likely the world will laugh at this as ridiculous, or condemn it for pride, or scorn it as self-conceit: but if they will be pleased to weigh it in judgements scales, they will find it poised with a good intention, and make a just weight of conveniency against unaccustomariness: for though it is not usual, yet it is very requisite, especially to such young women which are orphans, who like small and weak vessels, that are destitute of guide or pilot, are left on the wide seafaring world to ruinous waves, and inconstant weather; even so young women are to the appetites of greedy men, and their own inconstant and changing natures, and want of experience to guide them, run on rocks, shelves, and quicksands of troubles, misery, and disgrace, not knowing what safe port or home to sail to; whereupon, and in which danger, I considering with myself, at last I thought it the safest way to swim in the full ocean, and not in the narrow channels, creeks, or obscure corners, lest I should be crushed to pieces, or drowned for want of sea-room; and surely were there a law to forbid all private meetings of young men and women, and that no women should marry, unless they be wooed in public, there would not be so many unequal matches, so many perjured consciences, so many devirginate and forsaken maids; neither would there be such floods of tears from sorrowful parents' eyes, for their undutiful children's actions that will choose without their good liking, and marry against their good wills: but they will be ashamed in public to choose dishonourably or indiscreetly: for the ears and eyes of a public assembly will be as reigns, to curb their unruly passions, and their applause and commendation will be as spurs to force them to a wise, choice, when in private wooings their passions become wild, and run loosely about, without bridle or check: wherefore I desire my friends and acquaintance to be as witnesses of my behaviour and words to my loving and matrimonial suitors; and in this you will be as parents to the fatherless, as judges to pleaders, and gods to men.
We approve of your discreet and honest resolutions, and shall wish you happy days.

div.head: Scene 5.
div.stage: Enter mistress, parley, mistress Trifle, mistress Fondly, mistress Vanity, and one of the grave matrons. Then enters a servant-maid.

sp.speaker: Maid.
sp.p: Mistress, there is a woman at the door that can tell fortunes.
sp.l: O let her come in, let her come in.

sp.speaker: Fortune-teller.
sp.p: God bless you young ladies.

sp.speaker: Parle.
sp.p: Can you tell fortunes?

sp.speaker: Fortune-teller.
sp.p: Yes that I can lady.

sp.speaker: Trifle.
sp.p: Tell me mine.

sp.speaker: Vanity.
sp.p: Tell me mine first.

sp.speaker: Parle.
sp.p: No, tell me mine first.

sp.speaker: Fondly.
sp.p: Nay, tell me mine first.

sp.speaker: Matron.
sp.p: Have patience ladies, and let her tell your fortunes by degrees, one after another: for she cannot tell them all at once.

sp.speaker: Fortune-tel.
sp.p: I must look in your hand, lady.

sp.speaker: Fortune-teller.
sp.p: By your hand you should marry richly, and keep open-house; you will have many children, and your husband will love you dear.

sp.speaker: Fondly.
sp.p: But will nobody love me but my husband?

sp.speaker: Fortune-teller.
sp.p: Yes, you will be well beloved, if you be kind and loving to others.

sp.speaker: Trifle.
sp.p: Now tell me my fortune.

sp.speaker: Fortune-tel.
sp.p: You, lady, will have two husbands.

sp.speaker: Fondly.
sp.p: You did not tell me I should have two husbands.

sp.speaker: Fortune-tel.
sp.p: No lady, your fortune is to have but one.

sp.speaker: Trifle.
sp.p: How long will it be ere I shall have one of my husbands?

sp.speaker: Fortune-tel.
sp.p: Not long, lady.

sp.speaker: Trifle.
sp.p: Will my husbands be handsome men?

sp.speaker: Fortune-tel.
sp.p: Your first husband will be a tall men, with a brown hair and complexion.

sp.speaker: Trifle.
sp.p: That complexion and stature I like very well.

sp.speaker: Fortune-tel.
sp.p: Your second husband will be of a middle stature, and of a fair hair and complexion.

sp.speaker: Trifle.
sp.p: O I like that stature and complexion better.

sp.speaker: Vanity.
sp.p: Tell me mine, tell me mine.

sp.speaker: Fortune-tel.
sp.p: You will have many courting servants, and two will fight for you.

sp.speaker: Vanity.
sp.p: And which shall have me?

sp.speaker: Fortune-tel.
sp.p: He that outlives the other.

sp.speaker: Vanity.
sp.p: Why, shall one of them be killed?

sp.speaker: Fortune-tel.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Vanity.
sp.p: I am sorry for that: for I could please them both. But look again, perchance he may be only sore wounded, and not killed outright.

sp.speaker: Fortune-tel.
sp.p: Your hand doth portend death to one.

sp.speaker: Vanity.
sp.p: And will he live long that I shall marry?

sp.speaker: Fortune-tel.
sp.p: I do not perceive his death in your hand.

sp.speaker: Vanity.
sp.p: I am sorry for that; for I shall not love him, by reason he killed one that loved me so well as to die for my sake.

sp.speaker: Fortune-tel.
sp.p: 'Tis only his fortune to live; but he ventures as much for your sake as the other.

sp.speaker: Vanity.
sp.p: That's all one: for I shall love him that's killed, more than he that lives, especially after I am married: for I shall love a dead servant beter than a living husband.

sp.speaker: Parle.
sp.p: You are so long a talking to the woman, as you hinder her from telling me my fortune. Come woman, read the fortune in my hand.

sp.speaker: Fortune-tel.
sp.p: You, lady, will die a maid.

sp.speaker: Parle.
sp.p: Out upon the witch, what devil told you that lie?

sp.speaker: Fortune-tel.
sp.p: I do not say you will die a virgin.

sp.speaker: Parle.
sp.p: I hope you do not see any children in my hand.

sp.speaker: Fortune-tel.
sp.p: There are many lines that do foretell children; but some are so small, and others so crossed and broke, as I cannot find a straight or perfect line: but here are lines that do foretell many suitors.

sp.speaker: Parle.
sp.p: That's some amends: for it had been a hard case, and very ill fortune, if I should have neither husband nor suitors.

sp.speaker: Matron.
sp.p: Come, come, ladies, pay the poor woman, and let her go.

sp.speaker: Trifle.
sp.p: Give her a crown for me.

sp.speaker: Fondly.
sp.p: And one for me.

sp.speaker: Vanity.
sp.p: And one for me.

sp.speaker: Fortune-tel.
sp.p: Heaven bless you ladies: for you will make me rich.

sp.speaker: Parle.
sp.p: Give her half a crown for me.

sp.speaker: Matron.
sp.p: Will not you give her a whole crown?

sp.speaker: Parle.
sp.p: There is no reason I should: for she hath given me never a husband.

sp.speaker: Matron.
sp.p: Well, good woman, let this be a warning to you, that when you come to tell young ladies their fortunes, that you be sure to give them all one husband a piece, if not two or three: for the more husbands you give them, the more money they will give you.

sp.speaker: Fortune-tel.
sp.p: I shall take your counsel, mistress.

sp.speaker: Parle.
sp.p: To die a maid, it cannot be, it must not be, it shall not be.

div.head: Scene 6.
div.stage: Enter the lady prudence, and her audience, and her suitor, who is a soldier, there being two standing places, opposite to each other a purpose, one for the suitor to woo and plead his suit, and another for the lady to stand whilst she gives her answer.
This rooing soldier was written by the lord marquess of New-castle.

sp.speaker: Souldier.
sp.p: Madam, I am come here to offer you a man, a gentleman, and a soldier, three titles in me, the person that loves you, honours you, and will serve and obey you, and think it no disgrace thus to alter the catechism of our old written matrimony: if you command the breeches, you shall not only have them, but the coat too; and when you are pleased to change the name of the sex, the grey mare shall be the better horse: for 'tis a shame for a man to control a woman, but always to obey and please them from the least to the greatest of their commands: for man never seems so much man, nor masculinely enthroned under the cloth of state, in his royal chair of courage, as when he is taken prisoner, and led captive by the female sex. Thus, fair divine lady, conquered, thus I beg, thus I yield, thus submit: wherefore lady, take me, and make yourself happy and me.

lg.l: No musk nor civet courtly words I use,
Nor frenchez-pan promises to abuse
Your softer sex, nor Spanish sweets to tell,
And bribe your quicker nostrils with the smell,
Or let a false tear down my cheek to fall,
And with dissembling kneeling therewithal,
Sigh myself into air: these fools disdain,
These quarter-wits, oh kick them back again:
Nor am I like a justice of the peace,
That woos you just as he would buy a lease;
Nor like an heir, whose tutor for his sake
So many lies of jointer-houses make;
Nor like a lawyer that would fain entail,
And when he's tried, doth make a jeofail;
Nay thousands more, that always do dissemble
For your sake, make my loving heart to tremble,
Lest you should be deceived.
Admired lady, fear not my profession,
All my drumheads, I'll beat them to soft silence,
And every warlike trumpet shall be dumb:
Our feared colours now shall be torn off,
And all our armour be condemned to rust,
Only my sword I'll wear, the badge of man,
Por to defend you and your honour-still.
Then madam take me thus your loving vassal,
When lying bragging kestrels will forsake you.
O take a man, and joy in him for life,
A swordman knows the virtue of a wife.

div.stage: Here ends my lord marquess's writing.

sp.speaker: Lady prudence.
sp.p: Gallant sir, should I accept of your suit, I should be either an enemy to myself, or you, or my country: as for myself, should I marry a soldier, I should be tormented with the cruelest passions: for if I love my husband, as sure I shall, I shall be perpetually frightened with his dangers, grieved for his absence, despair of his life: every little misfortune will be as his passing-bell; I shall never be at rest asleep nor awake; my dreams will present him to my view, with bleeding wounds, mangled body, and pale visage; I shall be widowed every minute of an hour, in my own thoughts: for as the senses are to the body, so the thoughts are to the mind, and imaginations in these, or the like cases, are as strong as a visible presence: for passions live in the soul, not in the senses; for a man is as much grieved when he hears his friend is dead or killed, as if he saw him dead or slain: for the dead friend lives in the mind, not the mind in the dead friend: but with these dreams and imaginations I shall grow blind with weeping, weak with sighing, sick with sorrowing, and deaf with listening after reports: and should you desist from that noble profession for my sake, I should prove as a traitor to my country, by taking away part of the strength and support, leaving the weakness to the force of the enemy: for a good soldier is a strong fort and bulwark of defence: indeed a skilful commander is to be preferred before a numerous army: for a number of men without order, are like dust, which the least puff of wind blows about; so an army, not being well commanded, is quickly dispersed, and suddenly routed upon the least error; besides, should you desist, you would bury your name in oblivion, when by your valiant actions, and prudent conduct, your memory will be placed in fame's high tower, and writ in large characters of praise. 'tis true, should I marry, I should prefer my husband's honour before his life, yet would I not willingly marry a man, whose life shall be set at the stake, and fortune still throwing at it, for that would make me live miserably: and who would wilfully make themselves miserable, when nature forbids it, and God commands it not?

div.head: Scene 3.
div.stage: Enter the lady parrot, and the lady Minion.

sp.speaker: Lady parrot.
sp.p: Shall we go and visit the lady gravity?

sp.speaker: Minion.
sp.p: No, she lives so solitary a life, as we shall meet no company there: for none go to visit her.

sp.speaker: Lady parrot.
sp.p:
Then let us go to the lady liberty, there we shall meet
company enough: for all the ladies in the town go to visit her.

sp.speaker: Minion.
sp.p: If she hath no men-visiters, I will not add to the number of her lady visiters.

sp.speaker: Parrot.
sp.p: You may be sure she hath masculine visiters, or else the ladies would never go to see her: for it is to meet the men the ladies go to see her, and not for her own sake.

sp.speaker: Minion.
sp.p: And the men go to see the ladies.

sp.speaker: Parrot.
sp.p: I believe some do; yet men are better company in the company of their own sex, than in the company of women.

sp.speaker: Minion.
sp.p: By your favour, the contrary sex agree best, and are better pleased together, than men with men, or women with women: but if the lady Liberty's house be the general rendezvouz for men and women, let us go.

sp.speaker: Parrot.
sp.p: Content.

div.head: Scene 8.
div.stage: Enter mistress Trifle, and mistress Vanity.

sp.speaker: Vanity.
sp.p: O my dear heart!

sp.speaker: Trifle.
sp.p: O my dear joy, how glad am I to see thee! But where have you been, that you came later than you promised? for if you had not sent me word you would come to me today, I had gone to you.

sp.speaker: Vanity.
sp.p: Why, where do you think I have been?

sp.speaker: Trifle.
sp.p: I know not where to think.

sp.speaker: Vanity.
sp.p: I have been at a silkman's shop to buy me a new gown; but I would not choose it before I had shown thee my patterns.

sp.speaker: Trifle.
sp.p: Let me see them.

sp.speaker: Vanity.
sp.p: What do you think of this stuff?

sp.speaker: Trifle.
sp.p: This is out of fashion; besides, 'tis not a mode-colour.

sp.speaker: Vanity.
sp.p: What think you of this tabby?

sp.speaker: Trifle.
sp.p: The colour is good, but it is not of a good water.

sp.speaker: Vanity.
sp.p: What think you of this satin?

sp.speaker: Trifle.
sp.p: The satin is a good glossy satin, but the colour is too pale.

sp.speaker: Vanity.
sp.p: But pale colours, 'tis said, are allamode in France.

sp.speaker: Trifle.
sp.p: Who says so?

sp.speaker: Vanity.
sp.p: A gentleman told me so which is newly come out of France.

sp.speaker: Trifle.
sp.p: Then he perchance could have told you all the French fashions.

sp.speaker: Vanity.
sp.p: So he did most particularly: for he said he went into France for no other purpose but to see and observe fashions.

sp.speaker: Trifle.
sp.p: I believe he only observed men's fashions, being a man, and not women's fashions.

sp.speaker: Vanity.
sp.p: Nay, he swore he observed the women's fashion more than the men's, by reason he knew it would make him more acceptable to our sex at his return, not only for discourse-sake, but for the kind rewards he should have for his intelligence; which rewards he hath found so full and plentiful, as he hath made such a beneficial journey, as he will go once every year, and stay a month or two, and then return.

sp.speaker: Trifle.
sp.p: For Jove's sake send him to me.

sp.speaker: Vanity.
sp.p: I will; but prithee choose my gown.

sp.speaker: Trifle.
sp.p: Let the gentleman that came out of France choose your gown: for he can put you into the French fashion.

div.head: Scene 9.
div.stage: Enter the lady prudence, and the amorous wooer: they take their places, and the assembly about them.

sp.speaker: Wooer.
sp.p: Sweet lady, your beauty hath wounded my heart, imprisoned my senses, and hath enslaved my soul, so as I am wholly in your power.

sp.speaker: Prudence.
sp.p: I will mask my beauty, and set you free.

sp.speaker: Wooer.
sp.p: A mask may shadow your beauty, but cannot extinguish it, no more than a dark cloud can the bright sun: and as the sun begets life, and gives light; so your beauty begets love, and gives delight to all that do behold it.

sp.speaker: Prudence.
sp.p: And as time brings death, darkness, and obscurity; so age brings wrinkles, and absence forgetfulness, burying love in the ruins of beauty.

sp.speaker: Wooer.
sp.p: My love can never die, nor hath time power to vade your beauty.

sp.speaker: Prudence.
sp.p: Nothing escapes times tyranny, but what the soul possesses.

sp.speaker: Wooer.
sp.p: You are the soul of beauty, and beauty the soul of love.

sp.speaker: Prudence.
sp.p: Such souls have no eternity, but die as bodies do.

sp.speaker: Wooer.
sp.p: O save my soul, and love me.

sp.speaker: Prudence.
sp.p: 'Tis not in my power: for love is free and resolute; it can neither be commanded nor entreated.

div.head: Scene 10.
div.stage: Enter the lady liberty, sir Thomas Letgo, sir William Holdfast, the lady parrot, the lady Minion, master dissuader, sir William holdfasts friend, being met at a feast at sir Thomas Letgo's house.

sp.speaker: Letgo.
sp.p: Ladies, you are become melancholy of a sudden: I hope you are not tired with dancing?

sp.speaker: Liberty.
sp.p: Yes saith, we want divertisements: wherefore prithee sir Thomas Letgo, send for thy affianced mistress to make sport.

sp.speaker: Letgo.
sp.p: I am ashamed she should be seen, or made known to this noble company.

sp.speaker: Liberty.
sp.p: O divulge her by all means, that the world may know you do despise her, and that you will marry her only because she is rich, and to obey your father's commands.

sp.speaker: Letgo.
sp.p: I will obey your commands, and send for her.

div.stage: He sends for her, in the mean time he is talking to another.
Enter the lady mute, holding down her head, and looking simply.

sp.speaker: Liberty.
sp.p: Sir Thomas Letgo, your wise mistress is come to welcome your guests.

sp.speaker: Letgo.
sp.p: She wants words to express herself, and wit to entertain them.

sp.speaker: Liberty.
sp.p: Your father knew you wanted not wit so much as wealth.

sp.speaker: Letgo.
sp.p: Many fathers leave their sons nothing but their follies and vices for their inheritance: but my father not having vices or follies enough of his own, hath left me another man's fool for an annuity.

sp.speaker: Parrot.
sp.p: Is she a fool?

sp.speaker: Liberty.
sp.p: O yes: for she seldom speaks.

sp.speaker: Parrot.
sp.p: That's a great sign of simplicity indeed.

sp.speaker: Liberty.
sp.p: She is a mere changeling: for when she doth speak, it is but, when she is questioned, and then for the most part she gives but one answer to all sorts of questions.

sp.speaker: Parrot.
sp.p: What answer is that?

sp.speaker: Liberty.
sp.p: Her answer is, she cannot tell.

sp.speaker: Holdfast.
sp.p: Lady, there may be such questions asked, as are beyond a wise man's understanding to resolve: but perchance she is sceptic, that doubts all things.

sp.speaker: Liberty.
sp.p: What do you judge the sceptics fools?

sp.speaker: Holdfast.
sp.p: A man may judge all those to be fools that are not sceptics.

sp.speaker: Liberty.
sp.p: I judge all those that think her not a fool, are fools.

sp.speaker: Holdfast.
sp.p: Then lady I am condemned: for I cannot give sentence against any of your sex, neither in thoughts or words.

div.head: Scene 11.
div.stage: Enter the lady prudence, and the country gentleman as suitor: they take their places, the assembly about them.
This wooing part of the country gentleman was written by the marquess of Newcastle.

sp.l: Country gentleman, madam, though I no courtier am by education,
Yet I more truth may speak, and here declare,
Your charming eyes turn wanton thoughts to virtue;
Each modest smile converts the sinfullest soul
To holy matrimony, and each grace and motion,
Takes more than the fairest face.
I am not young, not yet condemned to age,
not handsome, nor yet (I think) ill-favoured;
I do not swell with riches, nor am poor,
No palaces, yet have conveniences.
What though poetic raptures I do want,
My judgement's clearer than those hotter brains,
To make a jointure out of verse and songs,
Or thirds in oratory to endow you;
The mean betwixt extremes is virtue still:
If so, then make me happy, and yourself.
Courtier's may tell you that you may enjoy,
And marry pleasure, there each minute's time,
There is all freedom for the female sex,
Though you are bound, yet feel not, you are tied,
For liberty begins when you're a bride:
Your husband, your protection, and the court,
Doth cure all jealousy, and fonder doubts,
Which there are laughed at as the greatest follies,
If not by most, yet they're thought mortal sins:
'Tis heaven on earth for ladies that seem wise.
But you are virtuous, and those ways despise,
Therefore take me, that honour you for that.

div.stage: Here ends my lord marquess's writing.

sp.speaker: Prudence.
sp.p: Worthy sir, could I persuade my affection to listen to your sure, you should not be denied; but it is deaf or obstinate; it will neither take your counsel, nor be entreated. But since you woo so worthily, I shall esteem you honourable, as well you deserve.

div.head: Scene 12.
div.stage: Enter the lady parrot, and the lady Minion.

sp.speaker: Parrot.
sp.p: Sweet madam, I could not pass by your house for my life, but I must enter to see you, although I was here but yesterday.

sp.speaker: Minion.
sp.p: Dear madam, I am very much joyed to see you: for I am never well but in your company.

div.stage: They sit down both in one couch.

sp.speaker: Parrot.
sp.p: When did you see the lady gravity?

sp.speaker: Minion.
sp.p: I have not seen her these two days.

sp.speaker: Parrot.
sp.p: Lord, she is the strangest lady that ever I knew in my life, her company is so uneasy, and let me tell you as a secret, she hath a very ill reputation.

sp.speaker: Minion.
sp.p: If I thought that, I would not keep her company.

sp.speaker: Parrot.
sp.p: Since I heard that report, I have shunned her company as much as I could.

sp.speaker: Minion.
sp.p: Even so will I: for I would not keep anybody company that I thought were not chaste for a world. But who is her servant, can you tell?

sp.speaker: Parrot.
sp.p: 'Tis commonly reported sir Henry courtly is her servant.

sp.speaker: Minion.
sp.p: Out upon him, he is the veriest whoremaster in all the town; nay, if she keeps him company, I will not come near her, I'll warrant you.

sp.speaker: Parrot.
sp.p: Nor I, although she would fain be dear with me, and seeks all the ways she can to be great with me, sending her gentleman-usher every day to me with a how do you.

sp.speaker: Minion.
sp.p: No, pray do not be dear nor great with her, but let you and I be dear and great, and that will anger her to the heart.

sp.speaker: Parrot.
sp.p: That it will faith, therefore let us go tomorrow together and visit her, to let her see how dear and great friends we are.

sp.speaker: Minion.
sp.p: Content.

sp.speaker: Parrot.
sp.p: Agreed.

div.stage: Enter sir Henry courtly, as to visit the lady Minion.

sp.speaker: Minion.
sp.p: Lord, sir Henry courtly, I have not seen you these three days.

sp.speaker: Courtly.
sp.p: I was here yesterday, madam, to wait upon you, but you were abroad, than I went to wait upon you my lady parrot, but you were also from home.

sp.speaker: Parrot.
sp.p: So then I had but the reversions of the lady minions visit.

sp.speaker: Courtly.
sp.p: I can be but in one place at one time, madam.

sp.speaker: Minion.
sp.p: Why should you take it ill, madam, that he should visit me first?

sp.speaker: Parrot.
sp.p: Because I know no reason but that he should visit me before you.

sp.speaker: Minion.
sp.p: Why, my place is before yours.

sp.speaker: Parrot.
sp.p: But the love and esteem I have for him, is to be preferred before your place.

sp.speaker: Minion.
sp.p: How do you know but that I have as much affection for him as you have? And I am sure I have, and more.

sp.speaker: Parrot.
sp.p: Don't you believe her, sir Henry courtly: for i'faith she said but even now, that you were the veriest whoremaster in all the town, and cried, out upon you.

sp.speaker: Minion.
sp.p: And she said she would forbear the lady gravity's company, by reason you did visit her, which was scandalous.

sp.speaker: Parrot.
sp.p: What, do you betray me in your own house, when you said the same, and if I be not mistaken, before me?

sp.speaker: Minion:
sp.p: If you tell what I say, I will tell what you say.

sp.speaker: Courtly.
sp.p: Ladies, whatsoever you have said, or will say of me, I shall take it well: for it is an honour to be mentioned by fair ladies, although in the severest sense or manner, or sharpest words.

sp.speaker: Parrot.
sp.p: What, do you take her part against me?

sp.speaker: Minion.
sp.p: No, no, I perceive well enough that he takes your part against me, for which he is a most unworthy man.

sp.speaker: Parrot.
sp.p: No, he partially takes your part, which is base.

sp.speaker: Courtly.
sp.p: I will assure you, ladies, it is not my nature or disposition to delight in your displeasures; but my desire is to please all your sex, and I endeavour in my practice and behaviour to that end: wherefore, if I cannot please, it is not my fault.

sp.speaker: Minion.
sp.p: So you make us women strange creatures, as not to be pleased.

sp.speaker: Courtly.
sp.p: No, madam, men want those excellent abilities, or good fortunes, which should or could please you.

sp.speaker: Parrot.
sp.p: Faith madam, he will have much to do to descend himself against us both.

sp.speaker: Minion.
sp.p: Nay if you will join with me, we shall be too hard for him.

sp.speaker: Parrot.
sp.p: That I will, and help to beat him with arguments.

sp.speaker: Courtly.
sp.p: For fear I should argue myself more out of your favours than I am already, I will take my leave of your ladyships for this time.

div.stage: They both follow him, and say, nay, stay, slay.

div.head: Scene 13.
div.stage: Enter the lady prudence, and the courtier: they take their places, and the assembly about them.

sp.speaker: Courtier.
sp.p: Lady, you are the sun of beauty, from whence all your sex receive a light, which without that would sit in darkness; you only give them lustre; you are the only goddess men adore, and those men which do not so, if any such men be, they are damned to censure: as for myself, ladies have judged me handsome, and for my person's sake have given me favours; nay, they have wooed my love with great expenses, maintained my vanities, and paid my debts, ruined their own and husband's honour and estate, and all for love of me; yet do I sue to you with great humility, though many of your sex have courted me; and let me tell you, fair lady, that courtiers wives have freer access to masks, plays, balls, and courtly pleasures, than other ladies have, who beg and strive, and often are beaten back in rude disgrace.
sp.l: All which, fair lady, if you sum up right,
You'll find a courtier's wife hath most delight.

sp.speaker: Prudence.
sp.p: Fair sir, could person, courtship, garb, or habit win my love, you should nor could not be denied: but since my affection is not to be won by any outward form, or courtly grace, I cannot grant your suit; besides, the lives that courtiers live, agree not with my humour: for I had rather travel to my grave with ease, than inconveniently progress about, tiring my body out, lying in nasty lodgings, feeding on ill dressed meat that's got by scrambling; but at the best, a courtier's life to me is most unpleasant, to sit up late at masks and plays, to dance my time away in balls, to watch for grace and favour, and receive none; to gape for preferments, offices, and honours, but get none; to waste my estate with fees, gifts, and braveries, to run in debt prodigally, to receive courtships privately, to talk loud foolishly, to betray friendship secretly, to profess friendship commonly, to promise readily, to perform slowly, to flatter grossly, to be affected apishly; no prudent brain, or noble heart, would interweave the thread of life with such vain follies, and unnecessary troubles; besides, I had rather be mistress of my own house, were it a cottage poor, than serve the gods, if gods were like to men.

div.head: Scene 14.
div.stage: Enter mistress Parle, and mistress Vanity.

sp.speaker: Vanity.
sp.p: My dear comrade, what thinkst thou? will the gentleman we met at madam gravities lodging marry me, think you?

sp.speaker: Parle.
sp.p: I know not.

sp.speaker: Vanity.
sp.p: I verily believe he will.

sp.speaker: Parle.
sp.p: What reason have you to believe he will?

sp.speaker: Vanity.
sp.p: A very good reason, which is, he looked upon me two or three times, and at one time very steadfastly.

sp.speaker: Parle.
sp.p: If a man should marry all the women he looks on, he will have more wives than Solomon and the great Turk, adding the number of their concubines. But the more earnestly the gentleman looked on you, the greater sign he thought not of you: for thoughts are buried in fixed eyes.

sp.speaker: Vanity.
sp.p: You speak out of spite, because I am thought handsomer than you.

sp.speaker: Parle.
sp.p: I had rather your beauty should lie in your own and others thoughts, than it should be visible to the view of the world, or to be inthrown on a multitude of praises; but however, I am not spiteful, and therefore pray think not so for telling you my opinion of your no-lover.

sp.speaker: Vanity.
sp.p: You love your jest better than your friend.

sp.speaker: Parle.
sp.p: That's an old saying; but I love a plain truth better than a flattering lie.

div.head: Scene 15.
div.stage: Enter the lady prudence, and the bashful suitor, and his friend Mr. spokesman, and the assembly.
The suitor makes two or three legs, wipes his lips, and blows his nose with his handkerchief, hems twice or thrice, and trembling, begins to speak.

sp.speaker: Bashful suitor.
sp.p: Madam, madam, madam.

div.stage: This scene the lord marquess writ.

sp.speaker: Prudence.
sp.p: Speak sir, what is't you would say?

sp.speaker: Spokesman.
sp.p: Madam, his love and modesty doth check his speech.

sp.speaker: Prudence.
sp.p: Then speak you for him.

div.stage: His friend goes and stands behind him, and speaks, the dumb gentleman the while acts his speech.

sp.speaker: Spokesman.
sp.l: Madam, your presence, with you sparkling eyes,
Hath dazzled him, and struck him dumb with love;
Like to a bottle too much filled, I doubt,
Though's mouth's turned downward, nothing will come out.
Or like a bag-pudding in love he's cursed,
So stuffed, so swelled, and yet he cannot burst:
Or like a glass with spirits of high price,
No drop can fall when 'tis congealed to ice.
Sweet lady thaw him then, take him apart,
And then his tongue will tell you all his heart,
And gush it forth with more force far than those
Who dribble all their love away in prose.

sp.speaker: Prudence.
sp.l: I'm all for public wooing, so no stain
Upon my reputation will remain.
With a dumb husband's curse I'll ne'er be caught,
But a dumb wife a blessing may be thought.
And so farewell.

div.head: Scene 15.
div.stage: Enter sir William Holdfast, and his friend Mr. dissuader.

sp.speaker: Holdfast.
sp.p: Sir Thomas Letgo's mistress, that he is to marry, is a pretty lady.

sp.speaker: Dissuader.
sp.p: But I do not perceive he is very hasty to marry her.

sp.speaker: Holdfast.
sp.p: If she were mine, I would not prolong my wedding-day.

sp.speaker: Dissuader.
sp.p: For fear she should die, and you should lose her estate.

sp.speaker: Holdfast.
sp.p: No, I am not covetous: for my estate will maintain a wife according to my quality, although she bring no portion; and upon that condition I might have her, I would give a portion for her, so much I like and fancy her.

sp.speaker: Dissuader.
sp.p: And would you marry her if you might have her?

sp.speaker: Holdfast.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Dissuader.
sp.p: Pray tell me, what would you do with a fool? she would be neither good for breed nor conversation: for she might bring you a race of fools, and vex you with ignorant follies.

sp.speaker: Holdfast.
sp.p:
Why should you think her a fool? she neither appears froward, peevish, or spiteful; she hath a sober face, a bashful countenance, a natural garb; she is silent and pensive, which shows she is no fool; but if she were always laughing, or toying, or singing, or dancing, or simpering, or prating, or had an affected countenance, or affected garbs or postures, I should conclude her to be a fool. But certainly she must needs have a wise wit: for she seems melancholy and contemplative, which no fool is; she hears much, and speaks little, which no fool doth: wherefore I judge she hath wit, but either she is careless, and cares not to express it, or thinks the company fools, and therefore will not express it, or is so bashful, as she cannot express it; and there is nothing shows, or discovers wit so much as bashfulness, which shows the mind and thoughts so sensible, as they apprehend beyond another's perceivance, and so fearful lest they should commit errors in their actions and expressions, as they obscure their virtues and natural excellencies, for want of a confident assurance, and a good opinion of their own abilities; besides, bashfulness thinks the least natural defect
a crime, and every little error a disgrace, never to be rubbed out; they will blush at their own thoughts, and will pine almost into a consumption, if two or three idle words should slip out of their mouths, or that they should mistake an argument, or that their behaviour was not so or so: the truth is, they never think their actions or their words well enough done or spoken; they are the first that shall condemn themselves, and the last that shall give themselves a pardon: but prithee Ned, as thou art my friend, see if you can procure me, or watch for an opportunity, that I might speak with her alone.

sp.speaker: Dissuader.
sp.p: I think that were not difficult to be done; but I will inquire a way.

sp.speaker: Holdfast.
sp.p: Do not forget it.

sp.speaker: Dissuader.
sp.p: No, it is so remarkable you should be in love with so simple a creature, as I shall remember it.

div.head: Scene 17.
div.stage: Enter the lady prudence, and her suitor a divine: the divine goeth to the place where the suitors plead, and the assembly about them.

sp.speaker: Divine.
sp.p: Madam, I should not thus presume, did not my profession dignify me to a spiritual office, wherefore a fit suitor to a divine lady: and since my suit is holy, by reason marriage is sacred, despise me not.

sp.speaker: Prudence.
sp.p:
Worthy sir, all of your profession require a solitary habitation for studious contemplation to a holy life, wherein their thoughts are consecrated to devotion, that their doctrine may flow from a pure mind, in eloquent words, to the ears of their flock, to instruct them with the light of knowledge, and to lead them into the ways of truth; whereas marriage, although it be sacred in itself, yet it is rather apt to disturb than unite, especially a double marriage, which are of different natures: for there are two sorts of marriages, as a spiritual, and a corporal: the first is betwixt the gods and mankind; the other is betwixt man and woman: the one is by a consecration and communion of spirits, the other is by a combination and communication of persons; wherefore those that are married to Jove, ought to keep themselves pure in that unity: as for the marriage of combination and communication of persons, although it is requisite for the continuance of mankind, and civil commonwealths, yet to spiritual elevations is is a great hindrance: for though a woman, especially a wife, be accounted as a helper and comfort to man by her diligent attendance, and loving service, yet women are accounted not only unprofitable in learned schools, but obstructers to a studious life, for which women are not suffered to inhabit in universities, schools, or colleges; indeed we are in a manner banished from the sight or entrance thereinto, and men have reason so to do; since learning, especially divine learning, requires study, and study requires a quiet, solitary, and silent life; and certainly there can be neither solitariness
nor silence where women and children are: for nature hath made women and children to have restless spirits, unquiet minds, busiless active, and such voluble tongues, as it is impossible they should be silent, whilst life gives them motion; so that a woman is a very unfit companion for contemplations, wherein there should be no other company but thoughts, which thoughts in a divine, should be only such as are the inquirers and searchers of Jove's divine mysteries, and scholars to Jove's divine schools, and orators to explain and plead in Jove's divine laws, and servants to Jove's divine order, that they may be instructers and intelligencers of Jove's divine commands: and though women ought to be instructed in divinity, yet for the most part, women are obstructers and disturbers of divinity and divines; besides, the original woman was a tempter to sin, which all her effeminate posterity inherit as a natural right and gift from their great grandmother: and though divines ought to be industrious to cut off the entail of that original inheritance with their holy doctrine, quenching the fire of temptation with the spiritual dew of divine instructions, yet ought they not to run themselves into that fire they should quench, serving as fuel to increase it: wherefore those that dedicate themselves to Jove's church, ought to live separated from nature's daughters, lest they should yield to humane frailties, and become slaves to the effeminate temptations.

div.head: Scene 18.
div.stage: Enter mistress Trifle, and mistress parley.

sp.speaker: Trifle.
sp.p: Friend, I am come to ask thy counsel.

sp.speaker: Parle.
sp.p: Concerning what?

sp.speaker: Trifle.
sp.p: Concerning marriage.

sp.speaker: Parle.
sp.p: I will give you the best I can; but it is both difficult and dangerous to give counsel in so weighty a concernment as marriage.

sp.speaker: Trifle.
sp.p: You say very true; and being so weighty a concernment as you say, I am come for thy advice, not trusting to my own judgement, and thus it is: there is a gentleman that hath come two or three times through out street, and the last time he came, he looked up to my chamber-window; wherefore I conceive he will come a-wooing to me, therefore I desire thee to instruct me how I shall receive his addresses.

sp.speaker: Parle.
sp.p: Do you know who he is?

sp.speaker: Trifle.
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: Parle.
sp.p: Nor where he dwells?

sp.speaker: Trifle.
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: Parle.
sp.p: Nor from whence he came, nor whither he will go?

sp.speaker: Trifle.
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: Parle.
sp.p: What makes you think he will be a suitor to you then?

sp.speaker: Trifle.
sp.p: Because he comes so often through our street, and by our door, and hath looked up to my chamber-window; and these are sufficient reasons to believe it: for you may be sure he comes through our street for my sake.

sp.speaker: Parle.
sp.p: Truly I know not what counsel to give you; but as occasion shall offer itself, I shall think of you.

sp.speaker: Trifle.
sp.p: Prithee do; but I am in haste, and therefore cannot stay with you any longer: wherefore farewell.

sp.speaker: Fondly.
sp.p: O my sweet parley, I was told thou wert not at home, and I have been at all my acquaintances houses to seek thee out, to tell thee a secret.

sp.speaker: Parle.
sp.p: What secret?

sp.speaker: Fondly.
sp.p: Why there hath been a gentleman this day at my father's house, to treat with my father about marrying me; and when I marry, I'll bid thee to my wedding.

sp.speaker: Parle.
sp.p: You must bid me before you are married, if you will invite me to your wedding.

sp.speaker: Fondly.
sp.p: Yes so I will, I'll warrant thee: for I will not forget thee of all my acquaintance: but prithee tell me what my wedding-gown shall be of.

sp.speaker: Parle.
sp.p: Of white satin, or cloth of silver. But of what quality is the person whom you shall marry?

sp.speaker: Fondly.
sp.p: I cannot tell.

sp.speaker: Parle.
sp.p: What estate hath he?

sp.speaker: Fondly.
sp.p: I know not.

sp.speaker: Parle.
sp.p: How often hath he been with your father?

sp.speaker: Fondly.
sp.p: He never was with my father before this morning.

sp.speaker: Parle.
sp.p: Hath your father concluded the match with him?

sp.speaker: Fondly.
sp.p: I cannot tell.

sp.speaker: Parle.
sp.p: Hath your father spoke to you of him?

sp.speaker: Fondly.
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: Parle.
sp.p: Then how came you to know he came to treat of marriage?

sp.speaker: Fondly.
sp.p: My father's man told me he thought the gentleman came about such a business, because my father and he were very earnest in their discourse, and in private.

sp.speaker: Parle.
sp.p: If you know no more, perchance it is about some other business.

sp.speaker: Fondly.
sp.p: It cannot be about any thing else, because they were earnest and private.

sp.speaker: Parle.
sp.p: Perchance it was about borrowing of money, and borrowers use to be earnest, and desire their desires may not be known: wherefore they draw aside, and whisper out their wants.

sp.speaker: Fondly.
sp.p: No, no, I am confident it was about me.

sp.speaker: Parle.
sp.p: I wish you may do well.

sp.speaker: Fondly.
sp.p: I thank thee for thy good wishes, and I hope he will prove a good husband.

div.head: Scene 19.
div.stage: Enter the lady prudence, and the lawyer: they take their places, and the assembly about them.

sp.speaker: Lawyer.
sp.p: Madam, although there is a certain and set form of making deeds, wills, and leaves, and a form of marriage, yet I know no certain nor set form of wooing, but every one woos after what manner or form he pleases or thinks best, having no set rules to woo by: but I am come here to woo, and so to plead my own cause at the bar of affection, and you, as the judge, are to give the sentence, and to determine the suit: but as all other judges are to be free from partiality, or self-interest, as neither to be overswayed with either fear, pity, love, or covetousness, or the like; yet such a judge as you, and in the like causes as mine, may have the freedom of partiality or self-interest: wherefore, if no other plea can persuade you, take me for pity: for I am miserably in love, manacled in Cupid's fetters, bound with his bowstrings, and wounded with his golden arrows, from which nothing but your favour and compassionate sentence can release me, otherwise I must lie under the arrest of a wretched life, till such time as death set me free, or cast me into oblivion.

sp.speaker: Prudence.
sp.p: Worthy sir, as there is no certain nor set form of wooing, so there is no certain nor set form for the wooed to give a direct answer: and though pity may move a judge to give a favourable sentence, yet there is no judge will, or ought to make himself a slave, to set a prisoner free; but if such a chance should be, it must be by a stronger motive or passion than pity, to make them yield up their liberty: and marriage is a bondage, especially whenas sympathy doth not match the pair; and if Cupid hath wounded you with his golden arrows, he hath shot me with those that are headed with lead, from which wounds proceed nothing but cold denials: but howsoever I shall give you part of your desires, which is, I shall pity you, although I cannot persuade my affections to love you so much as to consent to marry you.

div.head: Scene 20.
div.stage: Enter sir Henry courtly, and his wife the lady jealousy.

sp.speaker: Lady jealous.
sp.p:
Husband I hear you have a mistress, but I do not wonder at it, for you have taught me (Although not by the former, yet by your present practice) to foresee the future event. First, our loves have grown to their full maturity, and therefore in nature, as vegetables, must shed their leaves, or like animals, at such a growth their strength decays, and in old age dies; thus we may guess by nature's revolution, the revolution of our love, though at first we could not dream, but we must discover our dreams to each other, and whatsoever we had heard or seen in each others
absence, when we met, we recounted to each other each object, and repeated each subject and discourses that our senses had presented to our knowledge; and not only what our senses had presented, but what our conception had conceived, or our imaginations had created: also we took delight to confer in our household affairs, and we were unquiet, uneasy, and restless, until we met, and had discoursed thus unto each other; and if either of us had been sick, or had perceived the least distemper in each others health, our grief was expressed by our tears, and by our sighs, which from our hearts did rise, and flowed with grief, which poured through our eyes. But now we begin to cast shadows of dissimulation, which shows our love is in an eclipse, and from a pretence of the confidence and assurance we have of each other, we begin to be careless of each others discourse or action, giving ourselves freedom and liberty to wander, not only from our home-affairs, but from our professed affections, to seek for pleasures and delights abroad, and only a seeming affection and delight remains at home: and thus by a juggling deceit, and false-glaced love, we shall in the discovery become enemies, and by a seeming wisdom, we shall become fools, and our follies, as well as our crimes, will destroy the unity of love, and the peace of matrimonial government; and though we should not break out into open war, yet we shall live factious, and our servants will be as commoners, siding with each party: but it seems your mistress hath learned your mind so perfectly, and knows your humour so exactly, and can match your appetites with pleasure so justly, as she hath worked out her designs skilfully, which is, to displace me, and to place herself in your affections, by which she can make a subtle advantage of your estate and fortune, I mean good fortune: for in bad fortune she may chance; nay, 'tis most likely she will desert you for those that will and do forsake virtue, chastity, and honour, are not likely to stick to misfortunes, as to follow banishment, or to live with poverty, to bear injury, to endure scorn, and to die in misery. True love may do it; but for those affections that are produced by incontinency, and not bound to honesty, and settled by constancy, will change more often than the wind, wavering from person to person.

sp.speaker: Courtly.
sp.p: Wife, I confess the amorous addresses I have made to other women; but though I have strayed in my actions, yet not in my affections: for my love is unalterably constant to you, as believing you are unalterably virtuous, and I do not only love your chastity, prize your virtue, honour your noble soul and sweet disposition, but I take delight in your wit, am pleased with your humours, admire your beauty, and esteem and believe you to be the most perfect and best of your sex. But wife, know, that my appetites, and not my affections, seek after variety: for the kissing of a mistress lessens not the love to a wife, but rather increases it, comparing the falseness and beastliness of the one, to the virtue and purity of the other.

sp.speaker: Jealousy.
sp.p: And shall my virtue and chastity be only rewarded with your good opinion?

sp.speaker: Courtly.
sp.p:
Virtue, wife, is a sufficient reward in itself, and the chastity of your sex is crowned with honour; but the reward I give you, is the free use as a copartner of my estate, and the mistress of my family: besides, I make you the chief care of my industry, the chief subject or object of my valour, the treasure of my life, the only possessor of my heart, and for your sake I shall neither refuse death or torment. Thus you are the soul of
my soul; and since you have my whole soul to you self, you may be well contented to lend my person to your neighbour's wife, daughter, sister, niece, or maid.

sp.speaker: Jealousy.
sp.p: And will you be contented that I shall likewise borrow of your neighbour?

sp.speaker: Courtly.
sp.p: No wife: for you can neither lend nor borrow without the loss of honour.

sp.speaker: Jealousy.
sp.p: Nay, rather than lose so great a loss as honour, I'll strive to be content, husband.

sp.speaker: Courtly.
sp.p: Do you so, wife, and I will strive and endeavour to be contented with my own wife.

div.head: Scene 21.
div.stage: Enter the lady prudence with two suitors, a citizen; and a farmer, who both plead or woo, and she answers. The assembly about them:

sp.speaker: Citizen.
sp.p: Madam, although I cannot woo in eloquent orations, or courtly solicitations, or learned definitions, being only bred to industrious actions, thrifty savings, gainful gettings, to enrich me with worldly wealth, and not to studious contemplations, poetical fictions, divine elevations, philosophical observations, state-politicians, school-contradictions, laws intrications, by which (Perchance) I might have gained fame, but not wealth: but fame neither clothes the naked, nor feeds the hungry, nor helps the distressed, neither doth it maintain a wife in bravery, where, if you will be mine, you shall sit in a shop all furnished with gold, and great sums shall be brought you for exchange of my wares; and while you sit in my shop, all street-passengers will stand and gaze on your beauty, and customers will increase, and be prodigal to buy, whilst you sell, not for the use of what they buy, but for the delight to buy what you sell; besides, of all saleable curiosities and varieties that are brought to the city, you shall have the first offer, and the first fruits and meats each season doth produce, shall be served to your taste; your clothes, though of the city-fashion, yet they shall rich and costly be; besides, to every feast the city and each citizen doth make, they will invite you, and place you as their chiefest guest; and when you by your neighbour's doors do pass, their prentice-bois and journeymen will leave their shop-boards, and run to view you as you go. Thus shall you live, if you will be mine, in plenty, luxury, pride, and ease.

sp.speaker: Prudence.
sp.p:
Rich sir, I may sit in your shop, and draw customers, but shall get no honour by them; I may sell your wares, but lose my reputation; I may be adored, worshipped, sought and prayed to, as for and to a mistress,
but shall never be counted as a saint; I may be rich in wealth, but poor of the world's good opinion; I may be adorned with silver and gold, but blemished with censure and slander; I may feed on luxurious plenty, yet my good name starve for want of a good fame: for a citizen's wife is seldom thought chaste, and the men for the most part accounted cuckolds. I know not whether it be a judgement from heaven for their cozening, or decreed by the fates for their covetousness, or bred by a natural effect of their luxury, which begets an appetite to wantonness; but from what cause soever it comes, so it is: wherefore I will never be a citizen's wife, though truly I do verily believe there are as many virtuous and chaste women, and understanding men that belong to the city, as in the country; and were it not for the citizen's wealth, more ancient families would be buried in poverty than there hath been, where many times a rich city-widow, or daughter, gives a dead family a new resurrection: wherefore, it is more prudent for men to marry into the city, than it is advantageous for women, especially such women that esteem a pure reputation before wealth, and had rather live in poverty, than be mistrusted for dishonesty.

div.stage: Then the citizen goeth from the standing-place, and the farmer takes it. The lady prudence keeps her place all the while.

sp.speaker: Farmer.
sp.p: Madam, although I cannot draw a line of pedigree from gentility, yet I can draw a line of peasantry five hundred years in length; and if antiquity is to be esteemed, my birth is not to be despised: as for my wealth, I am not poor, but rich for my degree and quality; and though it is not fit I should maintain my wife in silver and gold, yet I may maintain her with plenty and with store, clothe her in fine smooth soft cloth, spun from the fleeces of my flocks: but if you will be mine, you shall be crowned with garlands made of lilies, roses, violets, pinks, and daffidillies, and be as Queen of all these downs, where all the shepherds and shepherdesses shall give you homage, and worship you as goddess of the plains, bringing you offerings of their morning's milk, their butter, curds, and soft pressed cheese, and various fruits fresh gathered off their trees; also my kids and lambs shall sport and play, and taught to know your voice, and to obey, and every holiday you shall in arbours sit, shadowed from hot sunbeams, whilst country maids and country men which lovers are, shall dance upon the grassy green to the sound of the hornpipe, bagpipe, and such breathing music, whose pleasant strains, and plain-set notes, rebound in echoes from the high-cast banks, the lofty hills, hollow woods, and murmuring streams, besides other rural sports, to entertain your eyes and ears, and recreate your mind with mirth and harmless plays, to pass your time withal.
sp.l: No life so pleasant as the country life,
No woman so happy as the farmer's wife.

sp.speaker: Prudence.
sp.p:
Honest friend, could I as easily persuade my affections to your person, as I could to the condition of a shepherdess's life, or farmer's wife, you should be the only man I would choose; but since I cannot, I must only return you thanks for your good liking, in that you have preferred me in your choice, for which, may neither nipping frost, nor burning sun, nor blasting winds, nor weeds, nor snails, nor worms destroy your labours, nor ravenous
wolves, nor crafty foxes nor polecats, weasels, kites, or any such like vermin, fright or rob you of your young and tender breed; may all your grounds and flocks increase a treble-fold, your fleeces long and thick, your corn firm and full-cared, your grass sweet and broad-bladed, your trees so full of fruits, that every branch may bow under its load; and may your plenty store all the kingdom, that neither want nor famine may be feared or felt; may all your country neighbours, and labouring swains, respect you as their chief, obey you as their lord, and worship you as their god pan.

div.head: Scene 22.
div.stage: Enter sir William Holdfast, meeting the lady mute, she seeming as in a studious thought.

sp.speaker: Holdfast.
sp.p: Lady, you are in a serious contemplation. Pray what are you thinking of?

sp.speaker: Mute.
sp.p: I have heard that thoughts are free; but I perceive they cannot pass without questioning.

sp.speaker: Holdfast.
sp.p: I would not boldly intrude upon them, my humble desire is I might partake of the excellency of them.

sp.speaker: Mute.
sp.p: I suppose you think my contemplation is of heaven, and not of the world: for there is no subject which can make thought excellent, but what is divine: for the world corrupts them, nature deceives them, and speech betrays them.

sp.speaker: Holdfast.
sp.p: If your speech never betrays more than it doth now, which only expresses your wit, you may well pardon it; but I now find you are not so ignorantly simple as you are thought to be through your silence.

sp.speaker: Mute.
sp.p: I confess I have practised silence: for I am of years fitter to learn than to talk; and I had rather be thought ignorantly simple for being silent, than to express folly by too much speaking.

sp.speaker: Holdfast.
sp.p: But I wonder you will suffer you self to be laughed at for a natural fool, when your wit is able to defend you from scorns and scoffs, and is able to maintain its own arguments.

sp.speaker: Mute.
sp.p: If I had wit, there would be no honour in the arguing, no more than for a valiant man to fight with cowards; so wit to dispute with fools: but I had rather they should laugh at me, than I should weep for myself; yet there were none in that company that laughed at me, but were older than I, and the older they are, the more faults they have committed; and if they laugh at me for my little wit, I will scorn them for their many faults, and hate them for their vices.

sp.speaker: Holdfast.
sp.p:
The truth is, 'tis only fools that commit many faults, and take delight in their own follies, and do themselves hurt with their own errors; and not those that have wit: for they have ingenuity and prudence to foresee, and so escape errors, and the mischiefs that may follow: but you appear,
by not expressing yourself, to your disadvantage, and your silence doth you wrong.

sp.speaker: Mute.
sp.p: I care not how I appear in my outward aspect, so my life be honest, my actions just, my behaviour modest, my thoughts pure, and that I obey to the utmost of my power the laws and customs of duty, morality, divinity, and civility. But 'tis a sign of a foolish age, when silence is thought ignorant simplicity, and modesty accounted a crime; when in ancient times youth was taught sober attention, and it was imposed upon scholars to keep silence five years before they were suffered to speak, that they might afterwards be able to teach, and not always live to learn as schoolboys, which they would always be, if they spent their time in words, and not study and observe: and silence is a discretion that few women practise, being more apt to talk than men; for women are fuller of words than thoughts: but words should be weighed by judgement, in the balance or scales of sense, and delivered by the tongue through the lips by retail, which cannot be if they throw them out so fast: for there is required reason, time, and understanding, besides unstopped ears to hear them: but though mine enemies laugh at me for a fool, yet I have so much honesty, innocence, and modesty, to guard and defend my reputation, as they cannot wound that with their sharp words, nor laughing faces.

div.head: Scene 23.
div.stage: Enter the lady prudence, and her strange wooer, a man that had a wooden leg, a patch on his eye, and crook-backed, unhandsome snarled hair, and plain poor clothes on: he takes the wooers place, and the assembly about, gazing with smiling faces at the sight of such a wooer.

sp.speaker: Strange wooer.
sp.p:
Lady, I come not now to plead with flourishing rhetoric, to make that which is false to appear like truth, or paint a foul cause with fair smooth words: but my cause of request is honest, and what I shall speak is truth; nor do I strive to hide my deformities or vices: as for my outward deformities, they are visible to your eyes; but vices live in the appetites, passions, and affections, which are only expressed by the actions, and therefore the easier may be dissembled from the most part of the world, yet not from heaven, to whom I am to make a just account: and since my sins are only to the gods, and not you, fair goddess, I shall not at this time make a public confession of them; but I am come here to present you with my love, which love is as pure as unspotted angels, it hath no by-respects unto your wealth, beauty, or birth, but barely and merely to your virtue: in truth I come a-wooing to your soul, not to your body, but yet mistake me not, I would not have them parted. I cannot say my estate or birth deserves you, nor have I merits equal to your worth; but since my love is as pure as your virtue, it will be an equal match: and though you see my body a deformed bulk, yet I am not ashamed of it, because the owner, which
is my mind, is honest: for I never betrayed my King, or country, mistress, or friend, nor any trust that was imposed unto me by any, although a foe; I never shut my purse, nor sheathed my sword from helping the distressed, nor turned my back upon my assaulting enemy; I never stole good fame, nor robbed good names, nor stabbed innocency with slander; I never scorned those below myself, nor envied those above me; I never infringed the laws of honour, nor disturbed civil society; and though I cannot suffer an injury patiently, yet I never did omit a duty willingly: as for the truth of what I say, I have none to witness for me, as being a stranger, but my own words, from which this company (Perchance) may think self-love and great desire hath bribed my tongue; but if they do, their thoughts make truth no less, no more than eyes that are blind, ears that are deaf, can rob you of your wit and beauty: for though your wit they do not hear, nor beauty see, yet you possess them no less, their want only robs you of their admiration, not of the possession; and say I am blind of one eye, my other eye doth see, and I have hearing perfectly, which doth inform my knowledge and understanding, with that which makes my admirations and adorations perfect and sound within my heart, wherein your picture is printed on, which my soul doth view, and gazing, kneels with wonder and astonishment, that so much wit, wisdom, and virtue should be in one so young and fair: and if you cannot love me, despise me not; for my pure love is divine, as being divinely placed on you; and it would grieve my soul, to have the zealous fire and immaculate flame of my affection extinguished with your neglecting thoughts, and raked up in the ashes of your forgetfulness: but if any of my sex shall seem to jest, or scorn me for my outward form or shape,
sp.l: My courage and my sword shall take my body's part,
To cut their limbs, or thrust them through their heart.

sp.speaker: Prudence.
sp.p: Worthy sir, you must excuse me from answering you at this time: for I am taken on the sudden very sick.

sp.speaker: Strange wooer.
sp.p: I wish you health, although it were to be only purchased by my death.

div.head: Scene 24.
div.stage: Enter mistress Trifle, and a grave Matron

sp.speaker: Matron.
sp.p: What is the cause you weep?

sp.speaker: Trifle.
sp.p: Because my father will not get me a husband, and mistress fondly will have a husband before I shall have one: for I hear she is to be married, she is happier in her parents than I am: for my parents are unnatural, and take no care how to get me a husband, and to see me married.

sp.speaker: Matron.
sp.p: You may marry soon enough to repent.

sp.speaker: Trifle.
sp.p: I am sure I shall not repent: for to be a wife, is a condition I am most desirous of, and cannot be happy any other way.

sp.speaker: Matron.
sp.p: And wives think maids only happy, because they are not vexed nor troubled with a husband.

sp.speaker: Trifle.
sp.p: Such women deserve no husbands: for certainly a husband is a joy and a comfort, as being a companion and a friend.

sp.speaker: Matron.
sp.p: But husbands seldom keep in the company of their wives, and many times, instead of a friend, prove an enemy.

sp.speaker: Trifle.
sp.p: What, have you been at mistress Fondly's house?

sp.speaker: Servant.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Trifle.
sp.p: And have you enquired of her maid as I bid you, whether the report is true, that her mistress is to be married?

sp.speaker: Servant.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Trifle.
sp.p: And what said she?

sp.speaker: Servant.
sp.p: She said that a gentleman did treat with her mistress's father, but they could not agree: for the gentleman would have more portion than her father would give, whereupon the match is broke off.

sp.speaker: Trifle.
sp.p: I am glad of that: for I would not have her married before me for all the world. But did you not see mistress fondly?

sp.speaker: Servant.
sp.p: No: for her maid said her mistress, at the breaking off her marriage, almost broke her heart: for she hath so afflicted herself, and hath so wept and sighed, as she is fallen sick, and keeps her chamber.

sp.speaker: Trifle.
sp.p: Alas good friend, I pity her extremely, but I will go with her, and try if I can comfort her.

div.head: Scene 25.
div.stage: Enter the lady prudence, to give her answer to her suitor the stranger: the assembly standing about, the lady and suitor take their places:

sp.speaker: Prudence.
sp.p: Noble sir, the wit wherewith nature, time, and education hath endued my tender brains, is like new kindled fire, that sparkling flies about, the fuel being green, and newly laid to burn, there is more smoke than flame: but since the time I heard you speak, a newer fire is kindled in my heart, which equally doth burn with your professed affections; and though your person is none of nature's exactest pieces, yet your mind doth seem to be composed with all her best ingredients; and sure your thoughts set notes of honour, honestly, and love, by which your tongue plays harmony. 'tis not the satin skin, that's painted white and red, nor near-carved bodies, can win my love, nor wealth, titles, birth, nor crowned power; but truth, sincerity, constancy, justice, prudence, courage, and temperance, by which, as magistrates, your life seems to be governed, which life I wish the gods may crown with happy days, and in fame's tower long live your praise. I will not ask you from whence you came, nor what you are: for though you seem but poor and mean, your soul appears to me sublime.

sp.speaker: Stranger.
sp.p: And will you choose me for your husband, lady?

sp.speaker: Prudence.
sp.p: I shall be proud to be your wife, sir.

sp.speaker: Stranger.
sp.p: The gods are just to my pure love, rewarding it with your acceptance; but I must beg your leave for some short time of absence, and then I shall return, and claim your promise.

sp.speaker: Prudence.
sp.p: You have the liberty, sir.

div.stage: The lady gravity speaks to the lady prudence.

sp.speaker: Gravity.
sp.p: Lady, surely you are in a high fever.

sp.speaker: Prudence.
sp.p: Why, madam?

sp.speaker: Gravity.
sp.p: As to do so extravagant an action, as to marry a man you know not what he is, nor from whence he came, and may prove as deformed in mind as in body, as mean of birth, as poor in purse, as beggars that live on cold dry charity.

sp.speaker: Prudence.
sp.p: If he be poor, my estate will make him rich; if humbly born, his merits make him honourable; from whence he comes I do not care, and where he will have me go, I will wait upon him, never questioning to what place.

sp.speaker: Gravity.
sp.p: Her courage is beyond her wit.

sp.speaker: Liberty.
sp.p: For the example of this lady, I would have a law made, that there should be no more public wooing.

sp.speaker: Parle.
sp.p: She hath cast away herself.

sp.speaker: Minion.
sp.p: Who can help it?

div.stage: The assembly go out, holding up their hands as at a wonder.

div.head: Scene 26.
div.stage: Enter the lady mute, as being in a melancholy humour. Enter sir William Holdfast, as meeting her.

sp.speaker: Holdfast.
sp.p: Lady, why seem you so melancholy?

sp.speaker: Mute.
sp.p: My melancholy disposition is apt to catch hold on my evil fortunes, and both joining together, help to multiply my sad thoughts.

sp.speaker: Holdfast.
sp.p: Why should you be sad?

sp.speaker: Mute.
sp.p: How can I be merry, when I am left destitute of friends, and unacquainted with experience.

sp.speaker: Holdfast.
sp.p: Nature hath furnished you with all store, you need none.

sp.speaker: Mute.
sp.p: If she had, yet all the good seeds that nature and education hath sown in me, and sprouted forth in bud, are nipped with misfortunes, withered with sorrows, blasted with sighs, and drowned in tears.

sp.speaker: Holdfast.
sp.p: For what?

sp.speaker: Mute.
sp.p:
For being enslaved unto an unworthy person, who neither loves virtue, nor values honour, but laughs at my youth, and flings scorns on my innocency, which makes me almost murmur at heaven, and apt to think the
god's unjust, to let fortune betray me to power and tyranny.

sp.speaker: Holdfast.
sp.p: Trouble not yourself: for certainly your bondage may be taken off, if it be discreetly handled: for he seems willing to part with you upon easy terms; for you heard him offer to sell you.

sp.speaker: Mute.
sp.p: I wish I were worth your purchase.

sp.speaker: Holdfast.
sp.p: Would you willingly change him for me?

sp.speaker: Mute.
sp.p: I cannot be worse; and you seem so noble a person, as persuades me to hope I may be happy.

sp.speaker: Holdfast.
sp.p: And if I had the whole world, I would give it for you, rather than not have you; and I should think myself more enriched by the enjoyment, than if the gods made new worlds to present me.

sp.speaker: Mute.
sp.p: I have heard heaven protects the innocent, defends the harmless, and provides for the helpless; which if it doth, the gods will give me you.

div.head: Scene 27.
div.stage: Enter mistress Parle, mistress Trifle, mistress Fondly, mistress Vanity, and one of the matrons.

sp.speaker: Parle.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha, is this the young wife lady that all the world admired for her prudence and judgement?

sp.speaker: Vanity.
sp.p: Faith her judgement hath erred in her choice.

sp.speaker: Fondly.
sp.p: I am glad: for now I may marry to whom I will, for I cannot choose worse; and my father and mother did bid me, nay charged me to imitate her.

sp.speaker: Trifle.
sp.p: So did mine.

sp.speaker: Vanity.
sp.p: And mine.

sp.speaker: Parle.
