sp.p: Well, for my part I rejoice: for now we shall have the old way of wooing again, to embrace and kiss in corners, to hear amorous and wanton discourse.

sp.speaker: Fondly.
sp.p: That way of wooing is best.

sp.speaker: Vanity.
sp.p: You say true: for I hate this way of wooing, there is no pleasure in it:

sp.speaker: Parley.
sp.p: No 'Saith, to stand gazing and prating a mile asunder.

sp.speaker: Matron.
sp.p: You make short miles.

sp.speaker: Parle.
sp.p: Why, two inches is a lover's mile, and three a long league.

sp.speaker: Trifle.
sp.p: It was not likely she should choose well, or ever be happily married.

sp.speaker: Matron.
sp.p: Why so?

sp.speaker: Trifle.
sp.p: By reason she was cursed by all the maids, back-holders, widows and widowers in the town.

sp.speaker: Matron.
sp.p: But she had the prayers of all the married women.

sp.speaker: Parle.
sp.p: But she had the curses of all the married men: for they crowd in amongst the back-holders sometimes.

div.head: Scene 28.
div.stage: Enter sir Thomas Letgo, and the lady liberty.

sp.speaker: Letgo.
sp.p: Sweet madam, you are the goddess which my thoughts adore,

sp.speaker: Liberty.
sp.p: You flatter.

sp.speaker: Letgo.
sp.p: Love cannot flatter: for lovers think all their praises truth.

sp.speaker: Liberty.
sp.p: The lady mute is your goddess.

sp.speaker: Letgo.
sp.p: If there were no other goddess of your sex but she, I should become an infidel to love, nay an atheist, believing there were no such deity as love.

div.head: Scene 29.
div.stage: Enter the lady prudence, and intelligencer her woman.

sp.speaker: Intelligencer.
sp.p: Madam, all the town condemns you.

sp.speaker: Prudence.
sp.p: And do you condemn me too?

sp.speaker: Intelligent
sp.p: No, madam: for I am bound, as being your servant, to submit to your will, liking, and pleasure.

sp.speaker: Prudence.
sp.p: Why, the choice is honest: for they may swear I am not enamoured with his person: but had he been a fair youth, or known to be a debauched man, they might have justly condemned me, either for my fond affection and amorous love, or wild choice.

sp.speaker: Intelligencer.
sp.p: I'faith they may think your choice is wild, by reason you have chosen out of a labyrinth, not knowing where his beginning or end is.

sp.speaker: Prudence.
sp.p: Why virtue is the beginning, and happiness, I hope, will be the end.

sp.speaker: Intelligent
sp.p: I wish it may prove so madam.

sp.speaker: Prudence.
sp.p: But pray tell me, did you ever hear me speak worse than I did to him?

sp.speaker: Intelligent
sp.p: How do you mean, madam, in that you gave yourself away?

sp.speaker: Prudence.
sp.p: No, in that I did not present myself more eloquently.

sp.speaker: Intelligent
sp.p: Methought your speech did not flow so smooth as it was used to do, as if your tongue did know you did commit a fault in granting to his suit.

sp.speaker: Prudence.
sp.p: No truly; for my desire did outrun my speech: for desiring to speak best to him I loved most, obstructed my tongue, which made my words run unevenly.

sp.speaker: Intelligent
sp.p: That's a common misfortune: for when any one strives to speak wisely, they most often speak foolishly.

sp.speaker: Prudence.
sp.p: 'Tis true; for strife is an enemy to speech: for those that speak not free and easy, never speak well.
sp.l: For whenas passion wrestles with the tongue,
The sense is weak, and down the words are slung,

sp.speaker: 1 gentleman.
sp.p: 'Tis strange the lady prudence, that is so beautiful, rich, and nobly born, and hath so great a wit, should choose a man so poor and mean, and so ill-favoured.

sp.speaker: 2 gentleman
sp.p: In my opinion it is not strange: for certainly there is a sympathy between the spirits of virtuous souls, which begets love, although in deformed persons: and this is the true love; for that which proceeds from covetousness, or ambition, or is produced by the senses, is rather an appetite, which is apt to surfeit, or dies as soon as enjoyed, or turns with fortune's wheel.

sp.speaker: 1 gentleman
sp.p: Well, I wish for the lady's sake, who is known to be virtuous, her husband may prove as virtuous as she.

div.head: Scene 31.
div.stage: Enter a grave matron, mistress Fondly, mistress Vanity, mistress Trifle, and mistress parley?

sp.speaker: Matron.
sp.p: Ladies, do you hear the news?

sp.speaker: Parle.
sp.p: What news?

sp.speaker: Matron.
sp.p: Why mistress simple is gone very early this morning out of town with sir Anthony Gosling; and 'tis said they will be married before they return.

sp.speaker: Vanity.
sp.p: I cannot believe it: for she was the most unlikely to be married of any of us all.

sp.speaker: Parle.
sp.p: I perceive that maid that can have fortune to be her friend, shall not want a husband.

sp.speaker: Fondly.
sp.p: You say true; and fortune is a better friend than our parents are: for our parents are contented we should live maids all the time of our lives, when fortune (Most commonly) gives maids husbands at one time or other.

sp.speaker: Matron.
sp.p: Ladies, why do you complain of your parents for their wary care? who would not have you marry, but to such husbands as you may be happy withal, and therefore are cautious how to choose, when fortune makes matches at random.

sp.speaker: Fondly.
sp.p: I had rather marry at random, than not marry at all.

sp.speaker: Matron.
sp.p: Why then (Perchance) in stead of a worthy person, you may marry a base fellow; and in stead of a rich husband, a beggar.

sp.speaker: Parle.
sp.p: Those women that are curious in their choice, may chance to die old maids.

sp.speaker: Matron.
sp.p: 'Tis better to die an old maid, than to live a miserable life, which will be, if an unhappy wife.

sp.speaker: Vanity.
sp.p: There is no misery like being an old maid.
sp.stage: She sings a piece of an old song

quote.l: Oh that I were so happy once to be a wedded wife,
I would fulfil my husbands will all the days of my life.

sp.speaker: Parle.
sp.p:
I doubt I may sing the song that says,
Oh pity take upon me now some gentle body,
And give me the willow-branch, for no man will have me.

sp.speaker: Trifle
sp.p: And I may sing this old song.

quote.l: Although I be but poor and brown,

sp.speaker: Fondly.
sp.p: And I may sing this old ballad.

quote.l: Every bird can choose his mate,
The wren can do the same,
The fish and fowl their pleasures take,
But I, poor I, poor silly I,
Yea night and day I wear away,

sp.speaker: Matron.
sp.p: Come, come, ladies, you are all so desirous to marry, and so impatient because you are not married, as I doubt when you are married, your husbands may sing the song of cuckolds all a row.

sp.speaker: Parle.
sp.p: It were better for us that our husbands should be cuckolds, than we lead apes in hell.

div.head: Scene 32.
div.stage: Enter as weeping the lady prudence, and her woman, intelligencer.

sp.speaker: Intelligen.
sp.p: Why do you weep, madam?

sp.speaker: Prudence.
sp.p: Have I not reason, when one I chose for honesty proves false, and publicly strives for to disgrace me, by breaking of his promise, and appointed day of marriage?

sp.speaker: Intelligencer
sp.p: Perchance he could not come, some accident hath hindered him.

sp.speaker: Prudence.
sp.p: He might have sent me word the reason of his stay.

sp.speaker: Intelligent
sp.p: It is likely he is not so rich, as to hire a messenger.

sp.speaker: Prudence.
sp.p: Some would have done it for charity.

sp.speaker: Intelligent
sp.p: I'faith charity is lazy, and will not go without reward.

sp.speaker: Prudence.
sp.p: If he had loved me or honour, he would have found some means or ways.

div.stage: Enter her servant the Strange wooer.

sp.speaker: Stranger.
sp.p: My virtuous sweet mistress, what makes such showers of tears in sunshine eyes?

sp.speaker: Prudence.
sp.p: O sir, I thought you had forsaken me, and left me to the world's wild scorn.

sp.speaker: Stranger.
sp.p: I should sooner forsake life, fame, and heaven, than forsake you.

sp.speaker: Stranger.
sp.p: Will you have your friends to your wedding, mistress?

sp.speaker: Prudence.
sp.p: If you please, sir: for I am not ashamed of my choice, nor shall I be ashamed of my marriage.

sp.speaker: Stranger.
sp.p: Nor I, of myself; and for you, the gods may envy me.

div.head: Scene 33.
div.stage: Enter mistress Parle, mistress Trifle, mistress Vanity, mistress Fondly, and a matron.

sp.speaker: Parle.
sp.p: Shall we go to visit mistress simple? she that is now my lady Gosling, and bid her joy.

sp.speaker: Vanity.
sp.p: Yes, if you will: for I long to see how she looks, now she is a wife.

sp.speaker: Trifle.
sp.p: So do I, and to see how she behaves herself, since she is married.

sp.speaker: Matron.
sp.p: She is now, ladies, for the conversation of wives, and not for the society of maids; her discourse will be now of household affairs, as of housewifry, and of her husband, and of children, and hired servants, and not suitors and courtiers, not fashions, nor dressings; neither will she return your visits: for her visitings will be to other married wives, and her time will be spent at labours, christenings, churchings, and other matrimonial gossipings and meetings.

sp.speaker: Parle.
sp.p: Howsoever we will go visit her.

sp.speaker: Fondly.
sp.p: I wish we may see her husband with her, to see if he be kind to her, or not.

sp.speaker: Parle.
sp.p: If he be not kind to her, and hath been married but two or three days, he will never be kind.

sp.speaker: Trifle.
sp.p: I wonder whether he will kiss her when we are by.

sp.speaker: Parle.
sp.p: Yes certainly: for new-married men and their wives take a pleasure to kiss before company.

sp.speaker: Fondly.
sp.p: Hey ho, that married wives should have such pleasures, when maids have none.

div.head: Scene 34.
div.stage: Enter sir Thomas Letgo, with other gentlemen.
This scene of sir Thomas Letgo, the lord marquess writ.

sp.speaker: Letgo.
sp.p: O unfortunate villain! that I should be such a coxcomb, such a fool, to lose five thousand pounds at dice! Those bones spotted with the small pox, the great pox take them for me, and the plague to boot: for they have plagued me, and yet I have not a token left about me.

sp.speaker: 1 gent.
sp.p: You may borrow more.

sp.speaker: Letgo.
sp.p: Borrow, you puppy, you, my land's entailed, a perpetuity, I have nothing but for life, like a servingman's annuity, or an old lady's jointure, nobody will lend me any thing; and now I must eat grass and hay: for we are all mortal they say, and they choke me with that. Pox of my grandfathers and fathers provident wisdoms, with their learned counsels in the law; but I hope all their souls fry in hell for't, that's my comfort.

sp.speaker: 2 gent.
sp.p: 'Tis a hard case, that a young gentleman cannot undo himself for those fetters and bonds of parchment; truly it is cruel.

sp.speaker: Letgo.
sp.p: Ay, is it not Jack, to be tied thus, like a dog to a cupboard, and in chains too, that he cannot gnaw or bite them asunder?

sp.speaker: 3 gent.
sp.p: Faith sir, 'tis a strange thing, that a man should venture to play his money, whether it should be his or another man's.

sp.speaker: Letgo.
sp.p: No dick, you are deceived, I play whether his money should be mine or his. O unfortunate rogue that I am! and that foolish stargazer, the astrologer, never to see it in my nativity neither when he cast it! Those knaves and fools, to talk of things that they have no guess at what they are, as if the seven planets, or the twelve houses, had to do with a cast of dice, a fine nimble cheater is worth a thousand of them. Rogue that I am! And now comes in such a consideration into my brain upon my repentance.

sp.speaker: 1 gent.
sp.p: As how prey?

sp.speaker: Letgo.
sp.p: As how? why if I had this current running money, nay rather, it hath wings, and flies beyond the fiction of Pegasus: why, if I had it, how I would bestow it for the good of the commonwealth, as thus: what rich apparel, with embroideries of gold, and silver, and silk? what feathers and mistresses? what gilt Paris coaches, pages, and lackeys, sans number, in rich liveries? what coachmen, postilions, with six Flanders horses, to strike with amazement the whole street as I pass? what running horses, hounds, hawks, cocks, greyhounds? what delicious banquets, Spanish perfumes, most odoriferous, soft music, that should lull the soul asleep, sumptuous furnitures, so as I would surfeit the senses, and make the seven deadly sins live like princes?
sp.l: And set up sin and vanity to the height,
Since those are still the gentlemen's delight.
sp.p: But oh my money is gone, which cuts off all my hopes of exercising all those virtuous ways! well, let me cogitate, and boy, give me a melancholy pipe to cloud all hopes of joys with sadder thoughts.

sp.speaker: 1 gent.
sp.p: Truly 'tis pity he hath lost his money: for you hear how religiously he would have spent it.

sp.speaker: 2 gent.
sp.p: Most like a gentleman, I must needs say that for him.

sp.speaker: 3 gent.
sp.p: Most piously indeed; but prithee let us walk for a while, lest we should disturb his thoughts: no more discourse, but let us tie our tongues.

sp.speaker: 1 gent.
sp.p: Content, till his be loose.

div.stage: They sit mute a time, while he sits musing.

sp.speaker: 2 gent.
sp.p: What contemplation now?

sp.speaker: Letgo.
sp.p: Pious and charitable ones. But this damned money, this renegade, this vagabond money!

sp.speaker: 1 gent.
sp.p: But if you had a statute to whip her home to her own parish, it would do well.

sp.speaker: Letgo.
sp.p: I Jack, but there is no such law, the more the pity; but this abominable money disorders all the world. What work makes it betwixt parents and children, husbands and wives, brothers and sisters, masters and servants, landlords and tenants, citizens and their prentices, mistresses and their maids, and between Kings and their subject? Corrupts all the world, breaks friendship, betrays friends, raises rebellions, commits treason, and corrupts virgins: it is the pander and bawd to all business; the statesman is fed by this damned lady Pecunia, the lawyer serves her, the merchants her slave, the shopkeeper her vassal, and the countryman her tenant, lords and ladies her pensioners, and greatest monarchs pay tribute to her; the logician argues for her, the orator pleads for her, and many ecclesiasticals preach for her, the vicar general and his conclave are ruled by her, and the poor poet, she draws his copperas from his ink, and makes him flatter her. This horrid lady sorceress, so to bewitch the world! Is there no law against this enchantress, that thus doth still abuse the world, and all that's in it? The very soldier's sword is charmed by her, and all his guns are silent at her presence. This she-devil!

sp.speaker: 3 gentleman
sp.p: But I would you had your she-devil again for all that: but what pious and charitable consideration had you, if you had your money again?

sp.speaker: Letgo.
sp.p: Marry sir, first I would build an hospital for decayed ladies that were maimed in Venus's wars, losing a nose, or so, never yet any care taken of them, the more is the pity.

sp.speaker: 2 gent.
sp.p: Very good: and what next?

sp.speaker: Letgo.
sp.p: Next I would buy such a piece of ground, and build a bedlam, and then put in all such divines as preach themselves out of their power and riches; and I would put all such lawyers in, as pleaded themselves out of practice; and all such citizens as petitioned themselves out of trade.

sp.speaker: 3 gentleman
sp.p: These are good and pious acts: but would not you provide a place or means for such as were undone by playing at dice and cards, and the like.

sp.speaker: Letgo.
sp.p: No, they should have only fools coats to be known by, and I would be the master of them.
sp.stage: Here ends my lord marquess of newcastles writing

div.head: Scene 35.
div.stage: Enter mistress Parle, mistress Trifle, mistress Vanity, mistress Fondly, and a matron, to the lady Gosling: these all bid her joy; she thanks them in a low voice, and a constrained and formal behaviour, and a foolish grave countenance.

sp.speaker: Trifle.
sp.p: How doth your husband, madam?

sp.speaker: Lady Gosling.
sp.p: I hope he's well, he's gone abroad.

sp.speaker: Parle.
sp.p: You look pale since you were married.

sp.speaker: Gosling.
sp.p: I was not very well this morning: for I could not eat my breakfast; truly I have lost my stomach since I have been married.

sp.speaker: Vanity.
sp.p: Perchance you are breeding.

sp.speaker: Gosling.
sp.p: O fie, no surely; but yet my maid laughs, and tells me I am.

sp.speaker: Matron.
sp.p: I hope, lady, you are not breeding already? for you have not been married above three days.

sp.speaker: Gosling.
sp.p: I have heard that some have been with child as soon as they were married; and my maid told me she served a mistress, who, the next day she was married was with child.

sp.speaker: Matron.
sp.p: By my faith that was very soon.

div.stage: The lady Gosling pulls off her glove to take her handkerchief, a pretence to show her wedding-ring.

sp.speaker: Fondly.
sp.p: methinks it is strange to see you have a wedding-ring on your thumb.

sp.speaker: Gosling.
sp.p: You will come to wear a wedding-ring on your thumb one of these days.

sp.speaker: Trifle.
sp.p: What is the posy?

sp.speaker: Gosling.
sp.p: I like too well to change.

sp.speaker: Parle.
sp.p: 'Tis well you do: for if you did not, you could hardly change, unless your husband dies.

sp.speaker: Gosling.
sp.p: Heaven forbid: for I would not have him die for all the world; for he is one of the lovingest and fondest husbands that ever was.

sp.speaker: Matron.
sp.p: The first month is a fond month, lady.

sp.speaker: Parle.
sp.p: And are you fond of him?

sp.speaker: Gosling.
sp.p: Yes truly: for I hang about his neck when he is at home.

sp.speaker: Matron.
sp.p: But you will weary your husband, lady, if you hang a long time.

sp.speaker: Gosling.
sp.p: I would very fain you did see my husband.

sp.speaker: Parle.
sp.p: We much desire so to do.

div.stage: She calls her maid Joan: the maid answers as within, madam.

sp.speaker: Gosling.
sp.p: Is your master, sir Anthony Gossing, come home yet?

sp.speaker: Maid.
sp.p: No, madam.

sp.speaker: Gosling.
sp.p: In truth he is too blame to stay out so long, knowing I am not well when he is away.

sp.speaker: Vanity.
sp.p: Are you sick in his absence?

sp.speaker: Gosling.
sp.p: I am best pleased when he is with me.

sp.speaker: Matron.
sp.p: New-married wives are always so; but after they have been married some time, they are worst pleased when their husbands are with them.

div.head: Scene 36.
div.stage: Enter the lady prudence as a bride that's very finely dressed in glorious apparel, her bridegroom in poor old clothes: he leads her as to the church, limping with his wooden leg. The bridal guests seem to make signs of scorning as they follow.
They all go out but two gentlemen.

sp.speaker: 1 gentlem.
sp.p: methinks it is a strange sight to see such a bride, and such a bridegroom. I do imagine them to be like Pluto and Proserpine.

sp.speaker: 2 gent.
sp.p: Nay rather, they are like Venus and Vulcan.

sp.speaker: 1 gent.
sp.p: But she is too chaste to entertain a Mars to cuckold him.

sp.speaker: 2 gent.
sp.p: It is to be hoped she will take her liberty with variety: for extravagant love is seldom constant.

sp.speaker: 1 gent.
sp.p: If that rule prove true, he may be a cuckold indeed.

sp.speaker: 2 gent.
sp.p: 'Tis likely he will: for women choose to marry such deformed men a purpose; first to excuse their fault, thinking the world will never condemn them, their husbands being ill-favouredly misshapen, or thinking their husbands will be well content, knowing their own infirmities, to be a sharer.

sp.speaker: 1 gent.
sp.p: But I wonder she did not new-clothe him: for though he is not so rich to buy himself a wedding-suit, yet she hath means enough to buy him many several suits, and rich.

sp.speaker: 2 gent.
sp.p: There was no time to make him wedding-clothes, because he came not till his wedding-day.

sp.speaker: 1 gent.
sp.p: Well, let us go see them married, and wish them joy.

div.head: Scene 37
div.stage: Enter sir Thomas Letgo, sir William Holdfast, and two or three other gentlemen.
So far of this scene as sir Thomas Letgo's, the marquess of Newcastle writ.

sp.speaker: Letgo.
sp.p: Since my losses, I have such a desire of revenge, as my fingers itch to be at it, and the palsy is in my elbow with the imagination of throwing those partial bones, called by the vulgar, dice; they say they are square fellows, but I doubt it: well, have at them, whatsoever comes on't; for I long more for them, than the great belly that longed to bite her husband's nose, or to give him a box on the ear; or she that threw her loaf into a barrel of tar; and if I have not my longings, in my conscience I shall miscarry.

sp.speaker: 1 gent.
sp.p: Take heed sir, that you do not miscarry, if you have the dice.

sp.speaker: 2 gent.
sp.p: How can he do that? for he hath nothing to miscarry withal, not a farthing, his pockets swell not; 'tis but an imaginary child, a windy or watery mole, or a mooncalf; he needs no dice to be his midwife for the lady Pecunia, a mere timpany of the fancy, and nothing else.

sp.speaker: Letgo.
sp.p: O Jack, thou art cruel! there is nothing so horrid as truth to a gentleman, and such truths too. I know not what to do with myself: for I cannot be alone, those are such foolish fellows that have parts, as they call them, and I hate both them and their parts.
sp.stage: Enters the lady mute as passing.
sp.p: Look here is my foolish mistress, by the gods I'll play her, I'll set her you, sir William holdfast, what will you stake against her?

sp.speaker: Holdfast.
sp.p: Sir, a lady, and such a lady, is beyond price unvaluable.

sp.speaker: Letgo.
sp.p: Come, come, leave your courtship to ladies, and throw, and have at her.

sp.speaker: Holdfast.
sp.p: Why sir, with the lady's leave, I will set you five thousand pound.

sp.speaker: Letgo.
sp.p: Five thousand pound? why she hath two thousand pound land a year man, and is an heir.

sp.speaker: Holdfast.
sp.p: But I consider a wife is chargeable: for I shall maintain her according to her birth, and my own honour; besides, children will come on, and they are chargeable.

sp.speaker: Letgo.
sp.p: For her charge, I will maintain her as cheap as a changeling, a dairy-maid, or a kitchenwench: why, she is a fool, and for children, you will not have them the first day certainly; but her estate will maintain her, and make thee rich; besides, a witty wife is a curse, and a fool but a trouble.

sp.speaker: Holdfast.
sp.p: But I consider there are two jointures go out of her estate.

sp.speaker: Letgo.
sp.p: Why, they are so old, they will both pick over the perch the next fall, and die of the frownsies; or if not, I will present thee with a little ratsbane for them, to put in their caudles.

sp.speaker: Holdstast.
sp.p: Well sir, I honour the lady so much, as I will set ten thousand pound against her.

sp.speaker: Letgo.
sp.p: By the gods, make it but fifteen thousand, and here I set her.

sp.speaker: Holdfast.
sp.p: Content, and we will take one another's words, and these noble gentlemen shall be the witnesses.

sp.speaker: Letgo.
sp.p: With all my soul. Give me the dice, they that throw most at three throws with three dice, let them win: for three is the lady's number but first let me invoke them.
sp.l: Thou lady fortune, here I do implore thee,
Now metamorphosed into dice that's three
My better fate with sixes to be crowned,
Thy favourite winning fifteen thousand pound.

sp.speaker: Holdfast.
sp.p: Throw sir, without any more invocation of this various goddess.

div.stage: Sir Thomas Letgo takes the lady mute by the hand, and sets her close to the table they play on.

sp.speaker: Letgo.
sp.p: Come, you fool, stand here on my side, and now have at your money sir. Two fives and a six? 'tis well; again, two fixes and a five? I thank thee lady fortune, if I win, thou shalt never be called a whore again, but a virtuous and pious lady; once again, three sixes? Sweet lady fortune, how have they wronged thee heretofore, in laying their own follies to thy charge! Malicious lying detractors, that defame ladies thus.
sp.l: Here take the dice, which are so square and new,
And bid your fifteen thousand pound adieu.

sp.speaker: Holdfast.
sp.p: You will give me leave to throw sir (Throws) what is that, three sixes?

sp.speaker: Letgo.
sp.p: Well, again.

sp.speaker: Holdfast.
sp.p: Three sixes again? I vow I believe she is a virtuous lady indeed.

sp.speaker: Letgo.
sp.p: I cannot tell yet, I will not take upon me for the noblest lady in the world, throw again, and I will tell you.

sp.speaker: Holdfast.
sp.p: Why then have at your mistress; three sixes again? O virtuous lady fortune!

sp.speaker: Letgo.
sp.p: By the gods, Jack, the lady fortune is a whore, a pocky whore.

sp.speaker: 1 gent.
sp.p: Why did you meddle with her then? I knew you would get a clap.

sp.speaker: Letgo.
sp.p: Nay I have got two; but now I shall have a strict diet that will cure me.

div.stage: Here ends my lord marquess's writing.
When Holdfast hath won, he speaks to the lady mute.

sp.speaker: Holdfast.
sp.p: Are you pleased with my fortune?

sp.speaker: Mute.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Holdfast.
sp.p: It is an injury to nature to whisper out your words, but rather they should be blown abroad by fame's loud trumpet.

sp.speaker: Mute.
sp.p: Had I rhetoric, as I have none, the loudness of the voice would take away the elegance of the speech, and drown the sense of the subject: but I desire you, and all the rest of this company may know, I am so well pleased with the change, as for this act of fortune's savour, I shall become a votaress to her deity, for whom I will build an altar more famous than Mausolus' tomb; it shall be built with rhetoric, polished with eloquence, carved with allegories, penciled with fancies, and gilded with praise; the materials shall be wise brains, honest hearts, and eloquent tongues; on this altar shall burn the fire of life, and all the actions of industry shall be offered thereon.

sp.speaker: Letgo.
sp.p: What, can you speak?

sp.speaker: Mute.
sp.p: I am not dumb, although my name is mute.

sp.speaker: Letgo.
sp.p: You were almost as silent as if you were dumb, all the time you were mine.

sp.speaker: Mute.
sp.p: 'Tis true; but now I am set at liberty, my tongue can run freely.

sp.speaker: Letgo.
sp.p: Why, you are as much bound to him now, as you were to me before.

sp.speaker: Mute.
sp.p: I account this bondage a freedom: for none can be a slave that is bound to a worthy person, who hath a noble nature.

sp.speaker: Holdfast.
sp.p: Pray sir Thomas Letgo do not court my fortunate mistress: for though you thought her a fool, I know her to be both wise, and also to have a great wit.

sp.speaker: Mute.
sp.p: I fear my wit is but an infant-wit, and lies in swathling-clouts asleep in the cradle of obscurity: but time may give it growth, and practice strength, and experience may bring it into the light of knowledge.

sp.speaker: Letgo.
sp.p: If you had no affection for me, yet you might have had so much civility, as to have expressed yourself sociable.

sp.speaker: Mute.
sp.p: Civility doth not bind any one to divulge their own infirmities, as to express their ignorance by their discourse; besides, for my part, I was so bashful and fearful, lest I should cause errors, and make such defects as were not naturally in me, but only produced by innocent ignorance, which made me choose silence to shun scorns; but I found it was not a sufficient defence.

div.stage: Enter the lady liberty, and the other ladies. One of the gentlemen speaks to them.

sp.speaker: 1 gent.
sp.p: Here is a miracle, not only that the dumb speaks, but she that was thought a natural fool, proves a great wit.

div.stage: All the ladies laugh, and repeat scornfully, a wit, a wit.

sp.speaker: Mute.
sp.p: That word, wit, that those ladies return in scorn, I with industry will make it like a reflection, to cause a double light, and give a greater heat of sense, reason, and judgement, fancy and phrase.
sp.stage: Then she speaks to sir William Holdfast.
sp.p: Sir, if I behave myself indiscreetly, impute it to an overflowing joy; and those follies I commit, are not by nature born, nor yet by education bred in me.

sp.speaker: Holdfast.
sp.p:
Sweet mistress, you can no more be guilty of a fault, than angels
in Jove's mansion. Fare you well, sir Thomas Letgo, the lady liberty will counterpoise your losses.

div.stage: Sir William Holdfast goes out, leading forth his mistress the lady mute, whereat sir Thomas Letgo frowns.

sp.speaker: Liberty.
sp.p: Let her go, sir Thomas Letgo: for if she be not a fool, for certain she is wanton, or otherwise she would not be so well pleased with change.

sp.speaker: Letgo.
sp.p: He hath affronted me.

div.stage: Sir Thomas goes out frowning. The company speak to the lady liberty.

sp.speaker: 1 gent.
sp.p: There is no change so visible, as the most opposite: but sir Thomas Letgo is both troubled and angry: wherefore lady liberty, you had best try to pacify him.

sp.speaker: Liberty.
sp.p: He is like little children, which despise what they have, but cry when they are taken from them.

div.head: Scene 38.
div.stage: Enter mistress Parle, mistress Trifle, mistress Vanity, and a matron.

sp.speaker: Parle.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha, prithee teach me something to keep in laughter, or I shall disgrace myself for ever.

sp.speaker: Matron.
sp.p: Are you so loosely set together, that you cannot hold?

sp.speaker: Parle.
sp.p: No, I shall burst out laughter at this ridiculous wedding, before all the bridal company, and so be thought rude.

sp.speaker: Matron.
sp.p: If you burst out nothing else, the company will excuse you: for weddings are composed of mirth and jollity, and every one hath liberty and leave to sport and play, to dance and skip about.

sp.speaker: Parle.
sp.p: But if the bridegroom limping should come to take me out to dance, I shall laugh in his face, which he will take as an affront, and then will kick me with his wooden stump.

sp.speaker: Matron.
sp.p: O no, he seems too wise to take exception, and too civil to kick a lady; he will rather kiss you, than kick you.

sp.speaker: Parle.
sp.p: I had rather he should kick me thrice, than kiss me once, by Jupiter. I would not be his bride, to be the empress of the whole world.

sp.speaker: Matron.
sp.p: It is probable, nor he your bridegroom.

sp.speaker: Fondly.
sp.p: Come away, the bride is going to bed, and you stand talking here?

sp.speaker: Parle.
sp.p:
To bed, say you? If I were she, I would first choose to go to my
grave. Hymen and Cupid bless me from such a bedfellow as the bridegroom.

sp.speaker: Trifle.
sp.p: Prithee let us watch, to see if we can descry whether he hath cloven feet or not?

sp.speaker: Parle.
sp.p: Should he have no cloven feet, yet certainly the original of his shape came from hell: for surely he was begotten by the devil, on some witch or another, and his clothes were spun by the devil's dam.

sp.speaker: Vanity.
sp.p: The truth is, he hath damnable old clothes on, they seem as if they were made of old rags, scraped out of dunghills.

sp.speaker: Matron.
sp.p: I perceive, ladies, you prefer beauty and clothes, before virtue and merit.

sp.speaker: Parle.
sp.p: I'faith virtue is too rigid to be beloved, and merit is but an incorporeal spirit, and an incorporeal spirit is no good bedfellow.

sp.speaker: Trifle.
sp.p: Wherefore I would have a handsome, personable, fashionable, courtly man.

sp.speaker: Fondly.
sp.p: Nay, if I could have my wish, I would wish for more than one man.

sp.speaker: Matron.
sp.p: The truth is, that one man would have too much by either of those ladies.

div.head: Scene 39.
div.stage: Enter sir Thomas Letgo, and the lady liberty.

sp.speaker: Letgo.
sp.p: Was it not enough to win, but to affront me with my losses?

sp.speaker: Liberty.
sp.p: Its true; they say losers have only leave to speak, but winners may be merry.

sp.speaker: Letgo.
sp.p: Was there no subject for his mirth but I?

div.stage: Enter sir William Holdfast, and his mistress, the lady mute.

sp.speaker: Letgo.
sp.p: You are a false cheating fellow.

sp.speaker: Holdfast.
sp.p: You are a base lying villain, for saying so.

sp.speaker: Letgo.
sp.p: You have cozened me of my mistress, and I will have her again.

sp.speaker: Holdfast.
sp.p: I have won her fairly and honestly, and I will keep her with my life.

div.stage: They both draw and fight. Mute runs to sir William Holdfast, and cries out.

sp.speaker: Mute.
sp.p: For heaven-sake leave off to sight for me, I am not worth the life you hazard for me.

sp.speaker: Holdfast.
sp.p: Sweet mistress, fear not, death hath no power on me, so long as you stand by.

sp.speaker: Mute.
sp.p: O let my sad complaints, like murmuring rivers, flow through your ears, that running into your heart, may move it to a gentle pity.

sp.speaker: Liberty.
sp.p: You should have let them fight, to see whether portune hath the same power on their swords, as she hath on the dice? whether she can dispose of life and death, as of honour and riches?

sp.speaker: Letgo.
sp.p: You may part us now, but we shall meet again.

div.stage: Sir Thomas and the company go out, only sir William and the lady Mute stays. The lady Mute weeps.

sp.speaker: Holdfast.
sp.p: My dear mistress, what makes your eyes to flow?

sp.speaker: Mute.
sp.p: As my tears flow through my eyes, so I wish my life may flow through my tears, then might you live in safety.

sp.speaker: Holdfast.
sp.p: Let not your love to me make waste of such tears, that every drop might save a life, nay save a soul, they are so pure and penetrating. But your fears do apprehend my foe more dangerous than he is.

div.head: Scene 40.
div.stage: A bed is thrust on the stage, as presenting the bride-chamber, the bride being in the bed finely dressed, and a company of young ladies her companions about her.

sp.speaker: Trifle.
sp.p: I'faith confess to us your maiden-companions, do not you repent?

sp.speaker: Prudence.
sp.p: So fat am I from repentance, as I should repent, were I not as now I am.

sp.speaker: Vanity.
sp.p: You will repent before seven years.

sp.speaker: Parle.
sp.p: Seven years? you mean seven days: for seven years to our sex, is seven ages; for maids and widow's account it so before their marriage, and married wives do account time so until their husbands die.

sp.speaker: Fondly.
sp.p: I'faith I think there are few women, but when they marry, hope to be widows.

sp.speaker: Parle.
sp.p: That's certain; and were it not for such hopes, men would hardly get wives.

div.stage: Enter the bridegroom, and a company of gentlemen and knights; then enters a servant with a rich nightgown or mantle, another servant with a rich cap, waistcoat, and slippers: then the bridegroom first pulls off his patch from his eye, then pulls off his bombast doublet, and then his wooden leg, and his snarled periwig, having a fine head of hair of his own; then puts on his waistcoat, cap, slippers, and nightgown, he then appearing very handsome, the company staring upon him, the mean time they as in amazement, he speaks to the ladies.

sp.speaker: Bridegroom.
sp.p: Fair ladies, as other men strive to adorn themselves, to mend their broken bodies, and patch up their decays with false and feigned shows, to cozen credulous women, that think them such as they appear, when they abuse your sweet and gentle natures: but lest my wife should think me better than I am, or expect more than I could give her, I formed myself far worse than nature made me; nor have I promised more than well I can perform.
sp.l: And if she loved me crooked, lame, and blind,
Now I am perfect, she'll not be less kind.

div.stage: The bed drawn off, the bridegroom follows, the men go out with him as in a maze, only mistress Trifle, vanity, and parley stays.

sp.speaker: Parle.
sp.p: Heyday, riddle me, riddle me, what's this? A man blind, and not blind, lame, and not lame, crooked, and not crooked, ill-favoured, and handsome.

sp.speaker: Trifle.
sp.p: I'faith it is like the tale of the great bear of Warwick.

sp.speaker: Vanity.
sp.p: What tale was that?

sp.speaker: Trifle.
sp.p: Why of a King that had three daughters, and when they were of marriageable years, the King their father asked them whether they had rather to have a husband that were a man a days, and a beast at nights, or a husband that was a beast at days, and a man at nights? and if they would marry, they must choose one of those that were sometimes men, and sometimes beasts, or otherwise they must never marry; but they, rather than to live old maids, were resolved to marry, were their husbands at all times beasts: so the two eldest chose to have their husbands men a days, and beasts at nights; for, said they, we can conceal their beastliness at nights, but not a days, for the light will divulge them to the public view of the world; but the youngest chose a husband, one that was a beast a days, and a man at nights: for, said she, I will please myself, not caring what the world thinks or says: for I am sure, said she, the world cares not what I think or say; whereupon they were all three married, and the youngest lady's husband was a great bear a days, but a very handsome man at nights.

sp.speaker: Parle.
sp.p: O that every woman were so well matched! for then they would be always pleased, and never jealous: for in the daytime, when men do court and plead loves suit, and point out private meetings,
sp.l: They have no words to woo, nor persons for to win,
And in the night their wives their arms do circle in.

sp.speaker: Trifle.
sp.p: But say your husband the he-bear, should meet a mistress she-bear, I believe you would be jealous then.

sp.speaker: Parle.
sp.p: I confess I should be somewhat lumpish.

div.stage: Enter mistress Fondly, and a matron.

sp.speaker: Fondly.
sp.p: Hey, ho!

sp.speaker: Parle.
sp.p: What is the cause you sigh?

sp.speaker: Fondly.
sp.p: Nature never made so handsome a man as the bridegroom.

sp.speaker: Matron.
sp.p: And you sigh because you are not the bride.

sp.speaker: Fondly.
sp.p: I'faith the devil tempts me to break a commandment.

sp.speaker: Matron.
sp.p: What commandment?

sp.speaker: Fondly.
sp.p: To covet my neighbour's goods.

sp.speaker: Parle.
sp.p: Why he is no part of your neighbour's goods, unless he be a good man.

sp.speaker: Fondly.
sp.p: Well, he is a goodly man, and whether he is a man that is good, I cannot tell: but howsoever I will never trust the outside more, I will never believe a patched eye is blind, nor a bunched back is crooked, nor a wooden leg lame, as long as I live.

sp.speaker: Parle.
sp.p: And if you will not believe it whilst you live, when you are dead, I doubt you will forget it; but howsoever the devil tempts me as much as you to covet him that's none of mine.

sp.speaker: Matron.
sp.p: Pray ladies give me leave to remember you, in that you said you would not be his bride, were it the way to make you empress of the whole world.

sp.speaker: Parle.
sp.p: 'Tis true; but then we were blind of one eye as he was; but now we see with both our eyes as he doth.

sp.speaker: Fondly.
sp.p: Come, let us go into the bride-chamber, and outdare his beauty on the forfeiture of our hearts.

sp.speaker: Parle.
sp.p: You need not go to seek love: for he will catch you, although you run away.

sp.speaker: Fondly.
sp.p: And you will catch love, if with the bridegroom stay.

sp.speaker: Parle.
sp.p: I doubt that.

div.head: Scene 41.
div.stage: Enter sir Thomas Letgo, and the lady liberty.

sp.speaker: Liberty.
sp.p: Let me persuade you to be friends: for if you seem to mourn for that which you made slight of, and to quarrel unjustly, and sight for for that you cannot have, nor is not rightly yours, you will be thought imprudent, shunned as a wrangling gamester, and accounted a ranting disturber, and laughed at for a fool, for setting such a mistress at a stake you thought too much to lose; but if you will save your reputation, you must seem to rejoice you are quit of her.

sp.speaker: Letgo.
sp.p: Well, I will take your counsel; and I have this satisfaction, that I am not the first man that hath been deceived by women, nor shall not be the last.

sp.speaker: Liberty.
sp.p:
That's true; and so generally it is known, as 'tis become an ordinary saying, and the saying will be made good as long as mankind lasts: for
though men may dissemble to women, yet it is women that deceive men, and we glory in it.

sp.speaker: 1 gent.
sp.p: Do you hear the news?

sp.speaker: 2 gent.
sp.p: What news?

sp.speaker: 1 gent.
sp.p: Why the bridegroom is proved to be the great Duke of Grandy's son.

sp.speaker: 2 gent.
sp.p: How so?

sp.speaker: 1 gent.
sp.p: Why you have heard that the old prince of Grandy had two sons, and the younger son would not be persuaded from going to travel, and it was reported he was drowned in a voyage by sea, for which his father mourned a long time, as loving him extremely; and you know, to add to his afflictions, his eldest son dies, so as he became as childless, until this time that his son is returned safe, for which he is the most joyed man that ever was, and is so fond of the prince his son, as he continually embraces and kisses him, and hangs about his neck like a fond bride.

sp.speaker: 2 gent.
sp.p: Why did he come so privately, and in a disguise?

sp.speaker: 1 gent.
sp.p: As for his private coming home, the reason was, that having oftentimes asked the mogul, to return into his own country, and being as often denied, and at last threatened to be destroyed if he should offer to go away, and quit the magor's service: for this prince was general of all his forces, and was the man that the merchants cried up to be another Julius Caesar, although they knew not of what birth or quality he was of; but to get away, he was forced to steal away in a disguise, in which disguise he wooed and won his lady, the now Princess: for whilst he lay privately in the city, until such time as he could handsomely and conveniently discover himself, he hearing the talk of the public wooing, and also of the virtue, beauty, and wit of the young lady, went to hear and to see her, whom he no sooner heard and saw, and being taken with her good fame, honouring her virtue, admiring her beauty, and being extremely delighted with her wit, became a lover, and also a wooer; but for the better trial of her virtue, he wooed her in his disguised, deformed shape, and unknown quality, left his dignity and wealth might have enticed her ambition, and not his merit, to have won her love, or his person might have catched her eye, but not his love her heart.

sp.speaker: 2 gent.
sp.p: The gods are just, rewarding in the end the good intentions with good success, and virtue with felicity.

div.head: Scene 43.
div.stage: Enter the bridegroom according to his dignity, as being a prince, richly clothed, and honourably attended with gentlemen with their hats off, he leading in the bride his Princess, and a great many ladies waiting on her: the prince and Princess sit in two chairs, and the rest of the company on each side of them to see an anti mask presented to them. When the antic-maskers had danced, a song was sung.
These songs following the lord marquess writ.

lg.head: Song.
lg.l: Virtue and honour you did take,
And beauty scorned as vading;
Thus you a goddess it doth make,
'Rove mortal ladies' trading.
They love the body, you the soul,
They shape, but you the mind,
Your love those grosser loves control,
Which shows their love is blind.
His wooden leg is thrown away,
The black patch for the blind,
The bunch on's back assuaged today,
As handsome as his mind.
This now is your reward, sweet madam,
The gods they are not lath
To give you one, handsome as Adam,
And thus enjoy them both.

div.stage: Then the maskers dance again, and after their dance another song.

lg.head: Song.
lg.l: Love's miracles not ceased be,
The lame to walk, the blind to see,
The crooked is made straight, 'tis true,
And these loves wonders made by you.
His body metamorphosed is,
By your ambrosia sweeter kiss;
Such power hath love when you do sip
The god's pure nectar from your lip.
All joys attend you night and day,
Be each to other fresh as may,
Renewing pleasures everyhower,
And sweeter than the sweetest flower.

div.stage: The maskers dance again, and after, another song.

lg.head: Song.
lg.l: Envious ladies now repine,
Since you are crossed,
In having lost
A prince so handsome and so fine.
Mourn in black patches for your sins,
Despair each curl,
And every pearl,
And throw away your dressing-pins.
Lay by your richer gowns of state,
For now you'll faint,
For all your paint,
When 'Think of your unhappier fate.
For these love-pitfalls they are stale,
And all despise
Your glancing eyes,
For all forced arts in love they'll fail.
Now let your specious gliding pass,
Or your lips fed
With biting red,
Despair, and break each looking-glass.

div.stage: Here ends my lord marquess his writing.

Then the maskers dance again, and so go out, the prince and Princess, and the company goes out all but a matron and some young ladies, who stay, and look upon each other very sadly, without speaking to each other.

sp.speaker: Matron.
sp.p: What, ladies, are you thunderstruck with the prince's honour, or are you blasted with the lightning of his splendour, or crushed with the wheel of her good fortune?

sp.speaker: Parle.
sp.p: Lord, lord, how blindly fortune throws her gifts away!

sp.speaker: Matron.
sp.p: One would think she had clear eyes, when she bestowed her favours upon the Princess.

sp.speaker: Vanity.
sp.p: She is become so proud, since she is become a Princess, as she will not look on us that were her companions; and she thinks scorn to speak to us: for she said not one word to any of us.

sp.speaker: Matron.
sp.p: She had no occasion to speak to you; but I am confident, if you speak to her, you will find her as civil and obliging, as ever she was.

sp.speaker: Fondly.
sp.p: I'faith we care not: for we can live without being obliged to her.

sp.speaker: Parle.
sp.p: They are not the happiest that have the greatest titles.

sp.speaker: Trifle.
sp.p: Pride will have a fall.

sp.speaker: Matron.
sp.p: I perceive it is hand to get the good opinion of the world: for you railed at her course, laughed at her choice, condemned her marriage, and now you envy her good success.

sp.speaker: Parle.
sp.p: We envy her? you are mistaken: for she must be of greater value, and we less worthy than we are, to raise an envy.

sp.speaker: Matron.
sp.p: Nay ladies, if you are angry, I will leave you.

sp.speaker: Parle.
sp.p: Then we shall be rid of a prattling fool.

div.stage: Enter three or four old ladies, the mothers to the young ladies.

sp.speaker: 1 old lady.
sp.p: O, wisdom in youth is a wonder.

sp.speaker: 2 old lady.
sp.p: Happy is that parent that hath a discreet child.

sp.speaker: 3 old lady.
sp.p: Such children give their parents honour in their graves.

sp.speaker: 4 old lady.
sp.p: Pray let us petition that a law may be enacted for this public wooing.

sp.speaker: 1 old lady.
sp.p: We shall not need to petition: for the Princess, I dare warrant you, will get the prince to enact a law for this public wooing for her fame, she being the only first that hath been wooed so.

sp.speaker: Old ladies.
sp.p: Well, daughters, make her your pattern.

sp.speaker: Trifle.
sp.p: Yesterday, that was the wedding-day, my parents did condemn the bride, calling her fool, and saying she was mad, and forbid me to imitate her.

sp.speaker: Parle.
sp.p: 'Tis no wonder our natures are so various, whenas our education are so inconstant: for we are instructed to imitate fortune, which is to be restless, and to spoil that good we have done.

sp.speaker: Vanity.
sp.p: Or to better the worse.

sp.speaker: Parle.
sp.p: No i'faith: for I perceive fortune hath more power to do hurt than good; for fortune ruins, or at least disturbs virtuous acts, and frustrates wisdom's counsels.

sp.speaker: Messenger.
sp.p: Ladies, the Princess desires your company to dance.

sp.speaker: Parle.
sp.p: Pray excuse me sir: for I have so great a pain on my left side, as I can hardly fetch my breath.

sp.speaker: Vanity.
sp.p: And I have such a pain in my head, as I dare not dance, for fear it should ache more.

sp.speaker: Trifle.
sp.p: And truly I have so straight a shoe, as it is a pain for me to tread a step.

sp.speaker: Fondly.
sp.p: And I am not well in my stomach: wherefore excuse us sir to the Princess.

div.head: Scene 44.
div.stage: Enter the lady parrot, and the lady Minion, and the lady Gosling.

sp.speaker: Parrot.
sp.p: God give you joy, I have not seen you since you were married.

sp.speaker: Minion.
sp.p: You are welcome into the married society.

sp.speaker: Gosling.
sp.p: I thank you madam. Truly I am so tired.

sp.speaker: Parrot.
sp.p: With what, madam?

sp.speaker: Gosling.
sp.p: With helping my neighbour the lady breeder to hold her back.

sp.speaker: Minion.
sp.p: Why, is she in labour?

sp.speaker: Gosling.
sp.p: She is brought to bed; but on my word she hath had a hard bargain: for she hath had a sore labour.

sp.speaker: Parrot.
sp.p: What hath God sent her?

sp.speaker: Gosling.
sp.p: A lusty boy. Indeed it is one of the goodliest children that ever I saw.

sp.speaker: Minion.
sp.p: But how chance she did not send for me to her labour?

sp.speaker: Gosling.
sp.p: She came on such a sudden, as she had hardly time to send for the midwife; but she was mightily troubled you were not there, she doubts you will take it ill.

sp.speaker: Parrot.
sp.p: We have reason: for if we could not have come time enough to her labour, we might have come time enough to the cup of rejoicing.

sp.speaker: Gosling.
sp.p: But she will bid you to the christening.

sp.speaker: Minion.
sp.p: That's some amends: but this hard labour of the lady breeders will fright you.

sp.speaker: Gosling.
sp.p: No: for I have as much courage as other married wives have, though truly, sir Anthony Gosling, my husband, was very loath I should go: for (Said he to me) prithee sweet duck do not go: I answered and said to him, my honey-love I must go, for it is the part of one wife to help another; besides, a gossipping company doth help to ease the women's pains; and if I go not to their labour, they will not come to mine.

sp.speaker: Minion.
sp.p: Why, are you with child?

sp.speaker: Gosling.
sp.p: No, but I hope I shall be shortly.

sp.speaker: Parrot.
sp.p: Come, we will go and chide your husband, that he hath been married a week, and his wife not with child.

sp.speaker: Lady Gosling.
sp.p: Yes, pray go chide him, and I will bear your company.

sp.speaker: Princess.
sp.p: Sir, pray persuade the unmarried ladies to dance: for I cannot entreat them.

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.p: That's strange: for ladies will dance without entreating; for no entreating will make them sit still.

sp.speaker: Princess.
sp.p: It seems they are not in their dancing-humour today: for every one finds some excuse for to deny.

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.p: Let them alone, and take no notice of their reserved humours, and they will dance without entreating; nay, they will entreat you they may dance.

sp.speaker: Gentleman
sp.p: If it please your highness, the ladies desire you would give them leave to celebrate your marriage with their mirth, and to express their joy with their dancing.

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.p: We shall take it as a favour to our nuptials.

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.p: Did not I tell you they would desire to dance?

sp.speaker: Princess.
sp.p: Truly I was so ignorant, as I knew not so much the nature of our sex.

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.p: You knew not so much of their follies.

div.head: Scene 46.
div.stage: Enter mistress Parle, mistress Fondly. Mistress Trifle, mistress Vanity.

sp.speaker: Vanity.
sp.p: Let us strive to make the bride jealous.

sp.speaker: Parle.
sp.p: That's impossible now; but you may not work to good effect some a half a year hence.

sp.speaker: Fondly.
sp.p: Why I have known a bridegroom leer her the next day he was married.

sp.speaker: Trifle.
sp.p: Perchance a bridegroom may: for men are sooner cloyed than women; but a bride will fondly hang about her husband's neck a week at least.

sp.speaker: Parle.
sp.p: A week? nay a month: for a woman is fond the first month, sick the second month, peevish the third month, coy the fourth month, false the fifth month, and cuckolds her husband the sixth month.

sp.speaker: Fondly.
sp.p: Then a married man sprouts horns in half a year.

sp.speaker: Parle.
sp.p: Yes: for they are set the day of his marriage, and some half a year after they are budded, but not so fully grown as to appear to the public view.

sp.speaker: Trifle.
sp.p: But will nothing hinder the growth?

sp.speaker: Parle.
sp.p: No i'faith, but death; and death, like a frost, doth nip those tender buds.

sp.speaker: Vanity.
sp.p: Which death, the man's, or the woman's?

sp.speaker: Parle.
sp.p: The woman's: for if the man dies, and his widow marries again, the dead husband is horned in his grave, and the living husband is horned in his bed.

sp.speaker: Vanity.
sp.p: Then their horns may be put together, as stags in rutting-time.

sp.speaker: Fondly.
sp.p: I had rather make horns, than talk of horns; therefore I'll go dance.

sp.speaker: 1 gentlem.
sp.p: Where have you been?

sp.speaker: 2 gent.
sp.p: At church.

sp.speaker: 1 gent.
sp.p: Did a fit of devotion hurry you to the church to pray?

sp.speaker: 2 gent.
sp.p: No i'faith, I went not to pray, but to join a pair of lovers hands in wedlock's bonds: for they chose me to be their father, to give them in the church.

sp.speaker: 1 gent.
sp.p: What lovers were they, that were so foolish to marry?

sp.speaker: 2 gent.
sp.p: So honest, you mean.

sp.speaker: 1 gent.
sp.p: There is more folly in't than honesty, in my opinion.

sp.speaker: 2 gent.
sp.p: Thou art an infidel, nay a very atheist.

sp.speaker: 1 gent.
sp.p: I am a naturalist. But who are they that are married?

sp.speaker: 2 gent.
sp.p: Why sir William holdfast and the lady mute.

sp.speaker: 1 gent.
sp.p: The truth is, he is a worthy person, and she is a virtuous and sweet lady: wherefore they deserve each other; besides, she is an heir, and he hath a great estate.

sp.speaker: 2 gent.
sp.p: He hath so.

sp.speaker: 1 gent.
sp.p: What, is the wedding kept private?

sp.speaker: 2 gent.
sp.p: Yes, there are only two or three friends; but I must go dine with them, therefore fare thee well, unless you will go with me: for you know you shall be welcome.

sp.speaker: 1 gent.
sp.p: I know I shall, therefore I shall go with you.

div.head: Scene 48.
div.stage: Enter the prince and Princess, and all the ladies and gallants, as knights and gentlemen: they dance upon the stage, and then go out.

div.head: Epilogue
div.l: Our authoress here hath sent me for her pay,
She's at the charge of wit to make the play;
But if you think it not worthy of praise,
Nor an applause of hands, her fame to raise,
She doth desire that it in pawn may lie,
Till redeemed by a better comedy.

div.head: Textual Notes
div.p: The textual notes below aim at making textual corrections readable in their immediate context and facilitating access to the source text. A five-dit number preceded by 'A' or 'B' represents an EEBO-TCP filenumber. A notation like "6-b-2890" means "look for EEBO page image 6 of that text, word 289 on the right side of the double-page image." That reference is followed by the corrupt reading. A black dot stands for an unidentified letter, a black square for an unidentified punctuation mark, a diamond for a missing word, and the ellipsis for a short span of undefined length. The corrected reading is displayed as a kewyord in context.
